column2: The State Department of the Public Advocate said today that a proposed project in West New York could force tenants to chose between paying $40 to $65 more a month "or being forced out" of their apartments.
President Antonio de Spinola swore in Portugal's new Cabinet today and called upon the Portuguese people to discipline themselves and to respect the new Government.
The State Senate's Democratic majority today chose next Wednesday as the day the 40-member Senate will vote on Governor Byrne's Proposed income tax.

Supporters of strong regulation of strip-mining beat back today a major effort by the friends of the energy industry in the House of representatives to substitute a weaker, industry-backed measure for the first Federal surface mine control law.

Commenting on an attack that left Assemblyman Byron M. Baer with a broken arm, the New Jersey Farm Bureau said today that farm visitors "should conduct themselves in a manner which would not precipitate such actions."

Italy's three major labor federations today announced a series of stoppages across the country next Wednesday to protest the aus terity measures adopted by the Government this month to bol ster a tottering national econ omy.

None of the telephone taps placed by the Nixon Administration on 13 Government officials and four newsmen ever disclosed any leaks of classified information to the press, according to evidence made pub. lic today by the House Judiciary Committee.
Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon said today the United States and Israel planned to sign an ongoing long term, economic assistance agreement in November.
Sitting at the controls of a giant auger may chine, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill today broke ground for the controversial $4.4-million "people-mover" at Bradley International Airport.
Vice President Ford disclosed today that he had listened to portions of two tape recordings of President Nixon's conversations with White House aides.
The president and chief executive officer of Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation said today inflation has forced the utility to cut back planned capital expenditures for 1975.
Brazil gave formal recognition today to the Republic of GuineaBissau proclaimed by insurgents in the territory ofPortuguese Guinea.

The Roosevelt Stadium here was converted today into a kind of outdoor Kingdom Hall as more than 10,000 people took over the ball park for a four-day Divine Purpose District Assembly of Jehovah's Witnesses.

Track and field officials gave preliminary approval today for athletes from mainland China to participate in the Asian Games. The anticipated move was another step toward giving Peking's athletes full status in world competition, including the Olympic Games.
Anthony Hanzlik, a photographer and a pioneer pilot for aerial photography who managed Flushing Airport in Queens since 1936, died Wednesday at his home in Flushing. He was 71 years-old.
Dr. Earl L. Bradsher, professor emeritus of American literature at Louisiana State University, died Wednesday at his home in Baton Rouge. He was 95 years old.

A commercial scuba diver failed to surface after a fiveminute underwater assignment at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday afternoon, and, more than 10 hours after he had slid into 100 feet of water with only an hour's supply of oxygen, the diver had not been heard from.

Archbishop Makarios arrived here from London yesterday and said he wanted the United Nations to condemn the coup in Cyprus-which he called a "violation of the independence of Cyprus by the Greek junta,"

The following is the text of the transcript of a White House tape of a Presidential meeting of July 24, 1971. The transcript was prepared by the impeachment inquiry staff for the House Judiciary Committee.

Forty-five prisoners at the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men took part in a 15-minute demonstration yesterday afternoon to protest the assignment of a correction officer to their eighth-floor cellblock.

Following is the text of a personal memo prepared byDavid R. Young, an aide to John D. Ehrlichman, for himself after a meeting with his superior. The memo, reflecting both Mr. Young's and Mr. Ehrlichman's concern that they not be pressed on whether information about the plumbers' operation had been passed to the President.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reversed yesterday the contempt of court conviction of seven persons in connection with the "Gainesville eight" trial.

President Nixon's defense lawyer told the House Judiciary Committee today that a 1973 tape recording the President has refused to give to the impeachment inquiry would prove that Mr. Nixon ruled out a "blackmail" payment to E. Howard Hunt Jr., a convicted Watergate burglary conspirator.

NEWARK, July 18--E. I. duPont de Nemours Co. and eight other chemical manufacturers that together control 60 percent of the nation's dye sales were indicted here today by a Federal grand jury on charges they fixed prices, pushing the cost of dyes to "artificial and noncompetitive levels."
The defense sought to establish today in the perjury trial of Lieut. Gov. Ed Reinecke of California that his rights had been violated by a former asisstant special prosecutor.

Louis D. Piana sailed Lou Lou to victory in the Etchells-22 Class on Long Island Sound today as the senior one-design skippers, returning after three junior days, enjoyed the best wind of the 76th annual Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week.

Hot dry weather over the Midwest growing areas and littie prospect for rain acted to drive grain and soybean prices sharply higher yesterday. On the Chicago Board of Trade wheat. corn and soybeans jumped the daily permissible limits in futures trading.
Leonard Bernstein will conduct only two works and will not play a scheduled piano concerto Sunday at the Tanglewood Music Festival, the Boston Symphony Orchestra said today.
The curator of Asian art at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts will fly to Washington today to return a stolen 11thcentury bronze figure of Vishnu to the Indian Embassy.
The Security Counci decided today to hear Arch bishop Makarios as head o state of Cyprus although hi Government there has beet overthrown. He is to speak to morrow afternoon.

The news story in yesterday's Times said: ". One died tonight in a hospital.... At least a dozen of the injured, about half of them children, were in serious condition. Two of the victims suffered severed legs, and rescuers found a child's foot beneath the displaced cannon."

Representative Hugh L. Carey declared yesterday that he was running against the Democratic party "establishment" while his opponent for the Democratic nomination for Governor, Howard J. Samuels, was "in bed with the bosses" he attacked in the gubernatorial campaign four years ago.

DIVERTIMENTO The setting is rather plain-an upper West Side restaurant with neat red tablecloths and hanging planters-but every evening at 7 P.M., you'll be able to hear music that's sweet enough and certainly unusual for dinnertime fare.

Following are the texts of two internal White House memorandums by Gordon C. Strachan to H. R. Haldeman concerning the 1972 election campaign. They were released today as part of the evidence of campaign practices gathered by the House impeachment inquiry staff.

The constant search for readily available, and inexpensive, sources of labor has taken an increasing number of American makers of apparel, electronics and other consumer products to Latin America and the Caribbean, it was reported this week.

Greece made a concession in the Cyprus crisis by agreeing to replace the 650 Greek officers in the Cypriote National Guard. The officers led the coup that deposed President Makarios and that brought Greece and Turkey to the point of confrontation. The officers' total withdrawal was a major demand of Turkey. [1:8.]
Drilling deep into the floor of the South Atlantic has revealed a former continental area that, like legendary Atlantis, has sunk some two miles beneath the sea.
Leonard Wolsey Cronkhite Sr., one of the first American recipients of a Rhodes Scholarship, died Tuesday. He was 92 years old and lived here.
The liner France will be withdrawn from service Oct. 25 after the last of seven scheduled summer North Atlantic runs, the French Line said today.

A prominent South Korean lawyer who defended the nation's leading poet and 10 students in political trials last week has been arrested, associates disclosed today. The lawyer, Kang Shin Ok, was taken from his office by plainclothes agents last Monday,

The House Banking Commnit: tee put off consideration today of a bill to extend. Federal regulation to financial holding companies' fund - raising issues after the Controller of the Currency, James E. Smith, said it could have "serious disruptive effects" on many nonbank companies.
John H. Meyer, founder of the women's apparel manufacturing concern John Meyer of Norwich, died Wednesday evening after a long illness. He was 50 years old and lived in Norwich, Conn.

The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose sharply to 239.8 from 228.8 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 179.9 on July 1, 1973. The following table gives the index and its components using 1967=100 as a base:

The House Judiciary Committee published today a mass of evidence that appeared to challenge President Nixon's contention that national security was the sole basis for White House involvement in wiretaps and the so-called "plumbers" operations.

President Nixon cited newspaper leaks, secret negotiations with foreign powers and Secretary of State Kissinger's concern about United States "credibility with its allies" in an effort to persuade the House...

King Hussein of Jordan, departing from a long-held stand, today recognized the Palestine Liberation Organization as the representative of Palestinians out side his own country and agreed with President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt that the Palestinians should have at separate delegation at the Geneva peace talks.

Against the strong recommendations of experts in his own department and elsewhere, Secretary of State Kissinger has evidently set the United States on a Cyprus course that carries maximum danger for everyone concerned--including the United States.

GREAT NECK, L.I. - Peter Fishbach of Great Neck, seeded fourth, beat Brian Anstey of South Africa, 6-2, 6-1, and gained the quarterfinals of the Nassau invitation clay-court tennis tournament today at the Great Neck Tennis Center.
The House Rules Committee took the first step today toward opening the final sessions of the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment inquiry to live television and radio coverage.

Greece made a concession in the Cyprus crisis by agreeing to replace the 650 Greek/ officers in the Cypriote National Guard. The officers led the coup that deposed President Makarios and that brought Greece and Turkey to the point of confrontation. The officers' total withdrawal was a major demand of Turkey. [1:8.]
More than usually, China is speaking in riddles these days. Among the most intriguing are, Who Silenced Golden Monkey? and Will He Stay Silenced? Golden
Officials of NBC have as signed themselves a July 31 deadline for the selection of new co-host for the "Today" program to succeed the late Frank McGee, a corporate M source disclosed yesterday.

Two Soviet astronauts who have spent the last two weeks aboard the space station Salyut tested their craft today for heir return to earth, concludng a Soviet rehearsal for next year's docking of a Russian Soyuz with an American Apollo space vehicle.

Turkey's Parliament met in secret session over the Cyprus crisis today and then adjourned until Saturday. The army moved thousands of reinforcements to a coastal plain across from the Mediterranean island.
The Communications Workers of America rejected today a date hour contract offer by the Bell Telephone System and directed its locals to take a strike vote.

Attorney General William B. Saxbe urged Federal prosecutors today to give top priority to fighting what he called "Twentieth century buccaneering" by real estate developers whose projects illegally destroyed coastal marshlands..
Motorists may face a 5 per cent gasoline shortage by winter unless they continue A fuel conservation efforts, according to a report prepared for the Senate Interior Committee.

Two of the world's leading metal companies-the Aluminum Company of America and the International Nickel Company of Canada-reported yesterday new highs in sales and earnings for the first half and second quarter.
The sensation, as press releases invariably put it, of last summer's Spoleto festival in Italy was Luchino Visconti's staging of "Manon Lescaut."

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., announced in Toronto yesterday that it planned to make a tender offer through a subsidiary for all of the common stock of ESB, Inc., for an estimated outlay of $157- million.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Company has reduced its 1974 capital spending plans by $106-million, citing tile unavailability of certain materials and the high cost of money.

Elliott Maddox, the center fielder, dropped out of the top 10 batters in the American League when he missed four games and most of the fifth after dislocating a finger. It wasn't his average that kept him out, but the number of times at bat, which fell below the 200 minimum.
Rejecting virtually all of the players' "freedom" demands, the owners made their first comprehensive package of proposals in the National Football League labor dispute yesterday.

The Health Department released yesterday the names of 32 health practitioners, most of them physicians or dentists, whom it had. suspended permanently from treating Medicaid patients because of abuses ranging from fraud to poor care. The list covers the period from 1971 to the present.

If the players' strike is not settled by next week, Coach Bill Arnsparger said today that rookies and free agents would dominate the New York Giants' line-up for their exhibition opener Aug. 3 at Houston.
A suspected holdup man was shot and killed last night by an off-duty detective who was critically wounded in a shootout in a beauty shop in St. Albans section of Queens, the police reported.
A Bronx Supreme Court jury has convicted an admitted' heroin addict on rape, robbery and sodomy charges for having terrorized three women in a Hunts Point apartment.
Three months before President Nixon appointed William H. Rehnquist to the Supreme Court, Mr. Nixon referred to "that group of clowns we had around there.

The beleaguered Franklin National Bank has lost $1.26billion, or 42 per cent of its deposits, since its financial problems surfaced early in May, according to figures released yesterday by the New York Clearing House Association.
Mayor Carl J. Delfino, ailing from a stroke, has resigned as mayor of this suburban city, paving the way for a special mayoral election in November.

The Drug Enforcement Administration announced today the arrests of 24 suspects in the United States and Bogota, Colombia, charged with operating a cocaine smuggling ring centered in a ski resort of Aspen, Colo.

If you happen to see a 6-foot 11-inch red-haired logger in the woods around Eugene, Ore. in the next few weeks, it won't be Paul Bunyan. It will be none other than Bill Walton, the former University of California, Los Angeles, center and No. 1 draft pick of the Portland Trail Blazers.

George H. Sibley, formerly a vice president, attorney and director of E. R. Squibb Sons, Inc., and a trustee of the Greenwhich Savings Bank, died Wednesday in Jamestown, Colo., where he lived. He was 75 years old and formerly lived here and in Pawling, N.Y.
Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, appeared today to be virtually certain of becoming chairman of the Senate's new Budget Committee as his last rival withdrew from contention.
Soviet Union plans to tap the heat of an active volcano to run a 300,000-kilowatt electricity station, the Mining lnstitute of Leningrad has announced.
The new Government on Cyprus says that life is back to normal here and indeed there is calm in this capital city ringed by 16th-century Venetian walls.

Communist gunners fired thousands of rounds of artillery and rocket fire into Government positions in South Vietnam's northern and central provinces, while a ground attack penetrated at least one Government outpost in the Central Highlands yesterday, the Saigon command said today.

One of the few things that hasn't gone wrong for the Pittsburgh Pirates this season is the pitching of Ken Brett, a left-hander who does a lot right when it comes to winning games.

Witt approval of Governor Byrne'( proposed income tax in grave doubt as it faces a decisive State Senate vote next Wednes day, the Legislature's Joint Ed ucational Funding Committee recommended today that a taN commission or convention undertake in the near future a "comprehensive study" of all state taxation, especially in the business field.

-An internal Food and Drug Administration memorandum says fewer fllan half the nation's pasta manufacturers meet Federal sanitation standards. The memo comes three years after congressional investigators attacked filth in the food industry.
A group of black financial institutions has formed a consortium to make a $2.9-million construction loan to a blackowned hotel in Atlanta.
Ken McElrath, who recently graduated from Tulane University School of Engineering, has developed and efficient, inexpensive process to remove silver from photographic waste solutions.

Watyne M. Collins, who defended' Tokyo Rose on a charge of making treasonable broadcasts on behalf of Japan in World War II, died Tuesday on an airliner on the way to San Francisco. He was 74 years old.
Nan Hoyt Lawrence, a vice president of the Women's Prison Association, was married here yesterday afternoon to John Luter, director
The House Judiciary Committee received today a 306-page summary of. evidence against President Nixon that "demonstrates," in the view of the committee staff, "various abuses or Presidential power."

In its harshest attack yet on the House Judiciary Committee, the White House accused the committee's counsel today of conducting a "kangaroo court" and challenged the right of its chief counsel to present articles of impeach ment against President Nixon.
The short Interest position on the New York Stock Exchange Dropped moderately in the montn ended July 15, according to figures issued by the exchange yesterday.

As the House Judiciary Committee continues its formal release of the massive volume of evidence it has developed in the impeachment inquiry, new public relations lines have begun to emerge from the White House.

John D. 'Ehrlichman, found guilty a week ago of conspiracy and making false statements filed a motion today asking for acquittal and a new trial on grounds that included the "facial expressions and gestures" of the presiding judge.

The House Judiciary Committee released today four more volumes of evidence gathered in its impeachment inquiry. Two volumes deal with the Justice Department's litigation with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and two deal with political contributions by milk producers and the 1971 decision by the Government to raise milk price supports. The makers of Lysol disinfectant have agreed to stop asserting that using the product around the house will kill germs that cause flu, colds or sore throat, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.
A large field has been named for the Suburban Handicap, listed for its 88th running today at Aqueduct. Ten horses are scheduled to compete, a surprising turnout in view of the fact

The Pentagon early today ordered the United States carrier Forrestal and other naval vessels toward Cyprus to be in position in case United States citizens have to be evacuted in the increasing tense crisis.

Honeywell, Inc. announced today it would lay off about 600 employes in its Boston computer operations this month as part of its over-all program of holding down "expense.. . in a worldwide economv of inflation.

The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, reported yesterday a 66.7 per cent climb in second-quarter profits, leading off what is expected to be a parade of sharply higher earnings in the coming week for most of the world's major petroleum enter'prises.

The State Public Service Commission announced yesterday that customers of the Long Island Lighting Company would pay $4.7-million in special fuel-adjustment charges on bills over the rest of the year. The additional costs, about 55 cents a month on the average residential electric bill, are necessary to pay disputed fuel bills to the New England Petroleum Corporation for residual oil delivered to the utility between September, 1973, and April.
Three Episcopal bishops disclosed plans yesterday to ordain 11 women as priests in defiance of the church's laws and practice.

A former international-class diver who won an event in a meet against the Soviet Union, has been helping young Essex County area prospects by making use of his psychology degree. Larry Moore, graduated with honors in 1973 from Cornell, placed in the National Collegiate meets for three years. and won the tower event when he competed for a touring Amateur Athletic Union team in 1971.

Gulf Oil Corportion said today it was surprised by the State Department's criticism of Gulf's decision to increase the price it pays for the Kuwait Government's share of crude-oil produced in that country.
Rear Adm. Alan B. Shepard, this country's first man in space and fifth to walk on the moon, said yesterday he planned to retire from the space program and the Navy on Aug. 1.

Secretary of State Kissinger will meet here Monday with Archbishop Makarios, the State Department announced today. At the same time, other officials said that the American Embassy in Athens recently dispatched a cable to Mr. Kissinger that detailed the direct involvement of the Greek military junta in the coup against the Archbishop.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Saturday, July 20--The Turkish troop landing in Cyprus will top the agenda at a Security Council meeting scheduled for 11 A.M. today. One Western diplomat predicted a cease-fire call would be the logical first-order of business.
Zoltan L. Sepeshy, former president of the Cranbrook Academy of Art in nearby Bloomfield Hills, died of cancer yesterday. He was 76 years old. He leaves his widow, a son and a daughter.

Premier Bulent Ecevit of Turkey reported that Turkish troops landed in Cyprus at 6 A.M. local time this morning after his Government had explored all diplomatic ways of solving the crisis brought on by the Cypdiote coup d'etat last Monday. The presidents of the Kings and Queens County Medical Societies deplored yesterday the Health Department's new policy of making public the names of suspended Medicaid practitioners, contending that the policy would destroy the patient's con-I fidence in his doctor, and thatI the Medicaid law itself was bad.

The softer side of rock'n'roll was exposed by the Schaefer Music Festival headliners, the group America, Wednesday' in Central Park. The trio, by no means new on the scene, still retains much' of its earlier acoustic appeal, still pays the same close attention to harmonies and performs every. thing with quiet freshness.

The ailing Generalissimo Francisco I Franco, his condition suddenly b worsened, delegated his powers r as ruler of Spain today to his M designated successor, Prince f( Juan Carlos de Borb6n.

Ralph Nader said today that white-collar crime by business-l men and government officials cost the American people at least $4-billion over the last 18 months, and he called for tougher penalties for those convicted of fraud and corruption.

Citicorp's controversial $850million offering of floating-rate securities, scheduled for sale to the public next Wednesday, have run into some investor resistance and may be scaled down slightly, according to Wall Street sources.

The Babe Ruth Birthplace Shrine and Museum in Baltimore was opened to the pubic, culminating a seven-year drive to honor the memory of the former New York Yankee slugger.

Huge crowds and traffic jams greeted eonid J. Brezhnev, general secretary of the Soviet Communist party, when he arrived here today to attend celebrations marking the 30th anniversary. of tile Communist party takeover in Poland.
Fred Hilton, the reputed Black Liberation Army member, was convicted yesterday in FederatDistrict Court in Brooklyn, of conspiracy in connection with a savings-bank robberv in Oueens last year.

President Nixon has a dark mark on his right temple, which has been examined by a dermatologist who said it was "all right," Mr. Nixon's doctor said today.

Representatives of eight South Jersey counties took the first steps here last night toward formation of a South Jersey public transportation authority and made plans to get legislative approval later this year.
William H. Maxwell, former features editor of The Star-Ledger of Newark, died Wednesday at his home here at the age of 93.

President Nixon nominated James E. Dow today to be deputy administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, a step up from his present position. Mr. Dow, 53 years old, now associate F.A.A. administrator.
Howard R. Hughes channeled more than $20,000 to Republican and Democratic candidates in California through a lobbyist for the company identified as a C.I.A. cover, state records showed today.

A tremendous tanK-car explosion and a chemical-fed fire devastated a railroad yard today, demolishing a trainmen's dormitory and forcing the evacuation of up to 30,000 people from a three-square-mile area here.

The eight-game hockey series between Team Canada '74 and the Soviet Union could be jeopardized by the Toronto Toros' signing of a Czechoslovak star, Vaclav Nedomansky. The series is scheduled to take place between Sept. 17 and Oct. 9. Team Canada '74 is actually a World Hockey Association allstar team. Its coach is the Toros' coach, Billy Harris, and several of its players will likely be Toros players.
A veteran inventor and businessman offers a coded system for the sale and delivery of merchandise that is designed to lessen the pilferage of goods by both customers and sales neonnle.

Golden Monkey, the pseudonymous author of Peking's most polemical wall posters, struck back today with a scathing attack on municipal leaders in the Chinese capital who appeared to have silenced him two weeks ago.

Gov. Milto J. Shapp signed a no-fault automobile insurance bill into law today and put his signature on another bill that forces government agencies to make almost all policy decisions at public meetings.

The Stella Wright Homes will be converted from high-rise to predominantly medium-rise development if a plan proposed today by the Newark. Housing Authority is approved by tenants of the controversial housing project.

Howard J. Samuels, who was accused by Representative Hugh L. Carey of Brooklyn of being "in bed with the bosses" Mr. Samuels attacked in the battle for the Democratic nomination for Governor in 1970, said yesterday that the circumstances were different then.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has at last lifted some of the mystery from the world's most complex --and erplexing-transportation network with the publication this month of two new Bus Guides for Manhattan and the Bronx.

HYDE PARK, N.Y. - The Vanderbilts always knew how to face adversity, and thus it came to pass that shortly after the turn of the century, they built a huge stable next to their estate here so that, even if it rained, they and their guests could go horseback riding and not get their fillies wet.

In their first summit meeting Prime Minister Harold Wilson and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing reached compromise agreements on some secondary issues here today. But the meeting demonstrated how much European relations have shifted in the last few months.
The American Motors Corporation announced today an increase of auto and Jeep prices averaging di $33, but the increase is con- U siderably higher on certain Cl popular model cars and trucks.

Consumer prices rose by I per cent in June, despite a slowdown in the pace of the rise of food prices, the Labor Department reported today. The June rise brought the index to a level that was 11.1 per cent higher than in June a year ago.

Soviet industrial produciion'increased 8.3 per cent In the first half of the year, well above the revised goal of 6.8 per cent, the Central Statistical Board said today.
The ailing Generalissimo Francisco Franco, his condition suddenly worsened, delegated his powers as ruler of Spain today to his designated successor, Prince Juan Carlos de Borb6n.

Charles Finley, a reporter for The Newark StarLedger, was arrested at his home here today on trespassing charges in connection with the incident at a Gloucester County farm in which Assemblyman Byron Baer suffered a broken arm.

European oil analysts said today a threat by Kuwait to cut production was behind the decision by the Gulf Oil Corporation and British Petroleum Company to raise the price they will pay for Kuwait state-owned oil.

Salvato Capelli's "The Devil Peter," the second-to-last entry in the Italian Theater Festival at the Provincetown Playhouse, is a coolly intelligent courtroom dissection of a self-confessed mass murderer in prewar Germany.

Only an America's Cup selection committee with an urgent need for information would have sent anybody to sea here today. It was one of those buck-ing-bronco days, with boats leaping and twisting in heavy waves whipped by 18-knot winds. But the committee whose job it is to choose a worthy Cup defender wanted to see how Intrepid and Courageous would perform in such blustery conditions.

A black musical version of Samson Raphaelson's play "The Jazz Singer" will be presented on Broadway next March or April by Barbara Gittler for the Jazz Singer Company. The production is budgeted at $850,000.

HACKENSACK - The Bergen County Bar Association has prepared a booklet for the public that tells clients what they should expect from a lawyer. Called "You And Your Lawyer," the booklet explains what a lawyer is, when he is needed, how a lawyer might handle a typical case and how to choose an attorney.
WEST PATERSON - An octagonal structure here with a cone-shaped shingle roof graces the highest peak in Rifle Camp Park in West Paterson, set atop what once was volcanic rock.

Controller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that in light of the disclosures of independent audits of city fiscal operations, the office of the Finance Administrator should be removed from control of the Mayor and be placed under the Controller.

HER name became a household word as a result of countless television commercials between 1949 and 1960 in which she repeatedly opened refrigerator doors and assured the nation's TV viewers that they could "be sure if it's Westinghouse."

The National Institute of Mental Health announced this week grants totaling nearly $5-million to train 215 racial and ethnic minority students in mental health professions and nine minority reporters in health and science writing.
Iraq has begun a five-year project to improve navigation along the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers to restore them to the prominent role they played in ancient history.

Treasury Secretary William E. Simon met with King Faisal today to discuss possible Saudi investment of oil revenues in the United States. Mr. Simon conferred with King Faisal at the summer palace in Taif, in the mountains 50 miles inland from this Red Sea port city, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

To the Editor: Perhaps the final irony of the American Revolution ("The Spirit of '74" by Thomas Fleming, June 30) is that Wroxton Abbey, the home of Lord North, King George III's First Minister, was eventually captured by the rebels.

Black and Puerto Rican school principals and supervisors who were recruited after a Federal court invalidated the old Board of Examiners Civil Service test for the job have passed an on-the-job evaluation at the same rate as their white colleagues and will probably obtain permanent appointments, according to papers filed in court here.

Brooklyn's first professional dinner-theater, at Cooky's Steak Pub in the Kings Plaza Shopping Center, opened recently with a production of Neil Simon's comedy, "The Last of the Red Hot Lovers."

The Rules Committee has wisely recommended to the House of Representatives that the Judiciary Committee's final debate on impeachment be broadcast by radio and television. JERUSALEM-The controversy over the place of religion in Israel is more than the fight of the orthodox against the tides of secularism familiar in other religions. It is basically social and cultural, a part of a wider debate on the nature of Jewish identity, in Israel and in the Diaspora.

" I AM determined to die with my name above the titles," Bette Davis likes to say in that imitably defiant way of hers, each syllable cropped so that it becomes an incident, each word stretched until it becomes an event. As usual, she means business.

Fears of a crisis between Egypt and the Palestine liberation Organization have been expressed here following President Anwar el-Sadat's endorsement of King Hussein's position on a Middle East settlement.

Leading molecular biologists have called upon their fellow scientists to defer a line of pure research because its "potential hazards" may outweigh its possible benefits. The scientists are concerned that scheduled gene-transplantation experiments could accidentally create drug-resistant germs or new types of cancer-causing viruses.

TRENTON-In what promises to be one of the most significant meetings in New Jersey's legislative history, the State Senate will convene here Wednesday for a final vote on Governor Byrne's tax reform program and the income tax it includes.

A shadowy Spingold knockout team championship continued at the Americana Hotel here yesterday afternoon with 16 teams in contention. OAK CREEK CANYON is one of the natural wonders of the Southwest. Carved out of brilliant red rock, it runs 13 miles along a delightful clear stream meandering through tree-lined campgrounds along the canyon bottom. The canyon is in the Coconino National Forest, south of Flagstaff, Ariz., and is a popular spot for vacationers.

Greeks reacted to the agreement on a cease-fire in Cyprus today with relief, humiliation and mild panic over widespread rumors of impending changes in the Greek Government.

Alexander Kartveli, the Georgran emigre whose designing talent gave American fighter pilots a series of rugged craft from the P.47 of World War II to the F-105 used in Vietnam, died Saturday at Huntington (L. I.) Hospital. He was 77 years old.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday it had won a $100-million order to furnish two more nuclear power systems and fuel to the Georgia Power Company. The units, each rated at 1.12-million kilowatts, would become the third and fourth units of the Alvin W. Vogtle nuclear power plant being built at a site in Burke County, 25 miles from Augusta, Ga., on the Savannah River.

A heat-seeking missile from a United States Navy F-4 Phantom jet accidentally hit a Navy helicopter today and the six men aboard the helicopter are missing, the Navy reported..

The nation's first death from plague in five years, coupled with increasing spread of the bacterial infection among animals, has led Federal health officials to step up protective measures against the ancient disease, which is endemic throughout the Western United States.

Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon was too much the maverick to be a reliable party man, too much the gadfly to be a hero of the Senate Establishment, too much the independent to be predictable even in his proved liberalism. He was a superb public servantnot in spite of those attributes but because of them.

Dr. Gallup reports that Vice President Ford has moved into a big lead for the Republican Presidential nomination, which is the most surprising news since Ron Ziegler last declared Richard Nixon not guilty. For this development, Mr. Ford has no one but himself to blame, although his nomination to be Vice President is basically responsible.

At today's assembly of dugout intellects for tomorrow night's All-Star game, the National League genius, Yogi Berra, named Henry Aaron as the third hitter in his batting order but declined to specify which outfield position the man with 725 home runs would play. "I want to see what Hank says," Yogi explained. "Can you give us an either or?" somebody asked.

Citicorp's controversial offering of floating-rate notes has run into customer resistance, and as a result it has been reduced to $650-million. The company had planned to sell $850-million of the novel securities.

More than 16,000, new doctors received licenses to practice medicine in the United States during 1973, registering the largest one-year gain in medical manpower ever, according to statistics compiled by the American Medical Association and reported in the A.MA.'s current Journal.

The Right Rev. John M. Allin, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church in the United States, has appealed to three Episcopal bishops to reconsider their plans to ordain I women in Philadelphia on Monday.

John Shea, who retired as a senior vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank in 1971, died Sunday in Holy Name Hospital, Teaneck, N. J. He was 67 years old and lived in River Edge, N. J.

An event that is to our minds almost as important as the publication of the English language version of "Larousse Gastronomique" in 1961 will occur this fall. It is the English translation of "Gastronomie Pratique," a volume we have treasured in our home library for more years than we can count. It is a 67year-old, seven-pound 1,281-page tome on classic and regional French cookery, and it is remarkable in many respects.
The New York Bank for Savings, the fourth largest mutual savings institution in the nation, said yesterday that it planned to sell the public $50million of floating-rate notes in two weeks.

The weight of seven years of army dictatorship has been lifted from the people of Greece. The satisfaction and rejoicing at the rapid developments in Athens stretch far beyond the exuberant throngs that poured into the streets within minutes of the succinct radio announcement that civilian rule had been restored to Greece.

Gov. Thomas J. Meskill has appointed four more Circuit Court judges to Common Pleas courts. The judges are leonard W. Dorsey of New Britain, William D. Graham of Hartford, Davis H. Jacobs of Meriden and Edward F. Stodolink of Stratford.
The Senate approved today a $25billion education bill containing a compromise provision to limit the busing of children for school desegregation.

The lawyer-adviser-agent for 300 of the world's best athletes puts it this way: "There is a fantastic explosion of sports which may very well envelop everybody and he the demise of sport. The average fan now is getting fed up.
Foolish Pleasure outlasted What a Sketch in the $28,800 Tremont at Aqueduct yesterday and then withstood a claim of foul to win the stakes by a neck.

The Federal budget would up the fiscal year 1974 with a deficit of $3.5-billion, the smallest red-ink figure since the fiscal year 1970, the Treasury and the Office of Management and Budget reported today.
The fight to acquire ESB, Inc., the world's largest producer of batteries, was intensified yesterday with International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., the original bidder,

Greece's new civilian Government under Premier Constantine Caramanlis moved quickly toward democracy by announcing the release of all political prisoners and amnesty for all political crimes. Several members of his Cabinet had been jailed or deported by the former military rulers. Its first meeting dealt with Cyprus and steps toward restoration of civil rights. [1:1-2.]

Two senior Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee who have not announced their positions on impeachment said tonight that they were seriously concerned about many of the allegations against President Nixon.

The legal battle whose outcome was decided today by the Supreme Court was joined three months ago in United States District Court here, when a lawyer from Texas filed a fairly routine type of motion asking that certain material be subpoenaed for possible use in a forthcoming criminal trial.

Richard J. Vizzini and two other firemen's union officials who led the first strike by the city's 10,900 firemen last Nov. 6 were placed on probation yesterday for three years with a warning by the court against strikes by city employes.
The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party held a plenary meeting today, apparently endorsing existing policies with little if any change.

Harry Freeman, vice president of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, said yesterday in Cairo he was hopeful of Egypt's acceptance of American investors but cautioned that it may take some time.

The Anaconda Company announced yesterday that it had reached a settlement with the new Government of Chile over the expropriation in 1971 of two of its subsidiaries, the Chile Exploration Company and the Andes Copper Mining Company.
Two major East Coast utility systems announced yesterday that they were cutting back their construction programs by more than $100-million each.

Not many people recognized the New York Stars' original defensive secondary, but even those fanatic few who did won't recognize the reshuffled secondary the Stars will use in Philadelphia against the Bell tonight.
President Nixon, abandoning his challenge to the Supreme Court's jurisdiction over him, said today that he would comply with this morning's Court decision on subpoenaed data "in all respects."
The Japanese Parliament began a special session today and, in an unusual move seen as a sign of his weakened leadership, Premier Kakuei Tanaka refused to give the customary opening address.
Premier Bulent Ecevit of Turkey hailed today the installation of a new civilian leadership in Greece as a step toward "a new era for democracy and freedom in our region.

On the eve of the House Judiciary Committee's historic debate on whether to recommend to the full House that President Nixon be impeached, Ronald L. Ziegler issued a call from out in the West that the House not "pass the buck" by sending the case to the Senate, thereby sparing the nation "a wrenching ordeal."

Nine buses carrying hundreds of migrant workers to New Jersey fields have been ordered off the roads because the vehicles are unsafe, the Federal Government announced yesterday. The disclosure came following the second inspection begun by a Federal-state task force whose aim is to protect the rights of the seasonal laborers.
The new civilian Government in Greece moved quickly today toward restoring democratic rights, announcing the release of all political prisoners and amnesty for political crimes.
A white woman and her Indian husband last night burned the house in which they reared their II children, rather than turn it over to chiefs of the Onondaga tribe.

Secretary General Joseph M. A. H. Luns said today that the Cyprus crisis had temporarily weakened the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's defenses on its southern flank. But he added that he thought the new Greek Premier, Constantine Caramanlis, could heal his country's rift with Turkey.
Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, proposed yesterday that the country return to standard time for six months each year.

Katharine D. Hardwick, dean emeritus of the School of Social Work of Simmons College in Boston, died Tuesday at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass. She was 88 years old and lived in Marstons Mills, Mass.

A jury of nine women and three men went into deliberation at 2:10 P.M. today to determine the fate of five persons charged with the kidnapping last March 6 of 9-year-old John Calzadilla for $50,000 ransom.
The good reception accorded Citicorp's huge offering of $650-million of floating-rate notes yesterday lifted some more of the gloom from the markets for corporate and taxexempt bonds.

Silver prices here, which usually follow London silver and gold price trends, went their own way yesterday. They started climbing immediately following the release of the news that the Supreme Court of the United States had ruled unanimously that President Nixon must yield the Watergate tapes. Meanwhile, gold and silver prices in London showed little change.

Like everybody else in the major leagues the Yankees, except for Thurman Munson and Bobby Murcer, their AllStar players, had the last three days off, during which they took stock of their fortunes in the American League's Eastern Division.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday price increases for footwear products, which it attributed to higher raw materials costs and a recent wage increase.
Coming off a less-thanwonderful year, Panasonic is going to try a new tack in the fall. It is going to concentrate its inventory and to some extent its advertising.
Constantine of Greece, deposed as King by the military Government while in exile last year, declined to predict today when he would return to his country.
President Nixon declared the state of New York a major disaster area today as the result of fierce storms and flooding since early July.

President Nixon was depicted by a former aide in testimony released today as being almost obsessive about trivial administrative matters and "very, very much in charge" of what went on in the White House.

Greek officials have privately warned the United States, Britain and Turkey that reported Turkish violations of the cease-fire in Cyprus were threatening peace and a restoration of a civilian government in Greece, diplomats and Greeks said today.
Sikkim's Chogyal, or King, administered the oath of office to live Cabinet ministers today, ending 332 years of monarchical rule in the Himalayan country, the Press Trust of India reported.

Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. set aside today an order by a New Orleans judge that restricted reporting of a murder trial. The effect of Justice Powell's ruling was to permit the reporting of court proceedings that Judge Oliver P. Schulingkamp had ordered withheld from publication or broadcast until after a jury was seated.

The International Chess Federation said that it would not tolerate future boycotts by the Soviet Union or other East European countries against the exiled Czechoslovak grandmaster, Ludek Pachman.

Young Billy Martin, a recent high-school graduate, upset ninth-seeded Raoul Ramirez, 6-3, 6-1, in the third day of the $100,000 Washington Star-News tennis tournament today. Stan Smith and Arthur Ashe advanced without trouble.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market moved higher yesterday in continued light trading. The most actively traded stock on the Amex was Geon Industries, which tumbled 7' points to close at 3 on a turnover of 144.000 shares.

Glafkos Clerides, the President of Cyprus, said today that it would be a "very unwise move under present circumstances" for the deposed President, Archbishop Makarios, to attempt to return to the island.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange scored their third consecutive advance yesterday as favorable economic developments continued to be reported. The Dow-Jones industrial average closed above the 800 level for the first time since July 1.

Hans Dietrich Genscher, the new Foreign Minister of West Germany, began a series of meetings with leading United States officials today, with emphasis on economic and defense issues.
Montclair yesterday appealed a state civil rights ruling that found that the town's Police and Fire Departments discriminated against members of minority groups.

Air pollution has killed 108,000 people prematurely in New York during the last 10 years, says a prominent researcher. The figure is based on an air pollution study by Dr. Herbert Schimmel and Dr. T. J. Marawski of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.
India will launch her first space vehicle in 1978, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today. It was the second announcement of a major technological advance by India in two months.
Portugal formally acknowledged today the right of her overseas colonies to self-determination and independence.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has announced the appointment of a curator in charge for the Cloisters, its medieval outpost uptown, and at the same time made known the promotion of nine women in the curatorial, conservation, library and education departments.

RIO DE JANEIRO-Volkswagen is diversifying in Brazil for the first time-into cattle. The Brazilian subsidiary of the West German auto maker, which is Brazil's biggest automobile manufacturer, has now begun a $30-million cattle industry in the Amazon Basin area.

Sean Morton Jr., who worked closely with Gary Davidson to found the American Basketball Association, announced the formation of World Team Boxing yesterday, with Arnold Cream, better known as Jersey Joe Walcott, as commissioner. The league needs 24 franchises to begin next January.

The prosecution rested Its case today in the 61/2-month trial of two leaders of the American Indian Movement, Dennis Banks and Russell Means, who are charged with 10 felonies in last year's 71-day Indian take-over at Wounded Knee, S.D.

Secretary of State Kissinger said today that although the Nixon Administration did not approve of South Korea's repressive policies, it had decided to continue economic and military aid for Asian security reasons.

The French Government approved today a budget of $51.6-billion for 1975, almost 14 per cent higher than estimated spending this year. The increase was expected to be entirely swallowed up by inflation.

About 250 praying, fasting supporters of President Nixon sang and handed out leaflets today in their vigil on the Capitol steps. The demonstration by the National Prayer and Fast Committee ends tomorrow.

Stan Smith survived a stiff challenge from 19year-old John Lloyd of Britain today in the $100,000 Washington Star-News tennis tournament.

Dr. Lowell E. Bellin, the city's Health Commissioner, submitted to the Board of Health yesterday a proposed resolution that would require all pharmacies in the city to maintain a medication history, or "drug profile," for every customer.

The widow of George Howard Hodge, a music arranger who was slain in his apartment near Lincoln Center last October, was arrested yesterday and charged with homicide in her husband's death. Beverly Donna Hodge being assisted by Harry H. Lipsig, lawyer, after she was booked on a homicide charge in the death of her husband, George Howard Hodge. Mrs. Hodge broke her foot in a recent accident.
A Federal jury found the A, P. supermarket chain guilty today of fixing prices in buying fresh meat and assessed the giant company a total of $32,712,081 in damages.

Armed convicts held 10 persons hostage for the second day in a state penitentiary library today, but a prison official said tonight that the "negotiation picture had brightened."

In the agonizing crisis at the begining of the last World War, when Neville Chamberlain was departing as Prime Minister and Winston Churchill was coming forward to take command, a loud cry went out across the House of Commons: "Speak for England!"

A young unemployed man was arrested last night and charged with stealing a bicycle and tennis racket from John F. Kennedy Jr., the 13-year-old son of the late President, in Central Park two months ago.

Tomatoes are selling in many stores in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut at prices that have not been seen here since the country began suffering galloping inflation in 1971. Tomatoes, available in many stores at 39 cents a pound, were 49 at one on Ninth Ave. and 43d St.
An increase of $130.56-million a year in Consolidated Edison's electric-rate revenues was recommended yesterday to the State Public Service Commission.

The United Automobile Workers began contract negotiations for 15,000 United States and Canadian American Motors Corporation workers today with a pledge not to bargain away their right to refuse overtime.

The Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development has given a $41-million urban-renewal grant to Newark's Housing and Redevelopment Agency to be used in six major rebuilding projects in the central part of the city.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubher Company, the world's largest rubber manufacturer, achieved the highest sales and earnings for any quarter or half in its history for the periods ended June 30.

In the suburbs of Detroit there were expressions of joy today, excited calling of friends to tell them that the Supreme Court had ruled that their schoolchildren would not be bused into Detroit schools and a sense of relief among leaders who had spent several years battling a court-ordered busing Proposal.

Democratic legislative leaders said today that they would begin preliminary meeting as soon as possible next month to reevaluate revenue-raising alternatives to the Byrne administration's income-tax program that died in the state Senate yesterday.

A scientific sample of 114 cases at a typical welfare center in Queens showed that 33 of the cases were ineligible for payment and 20 others were receiving overpayments, the State Welfare Inspector General reported yesterday.
Defense Department officials said today that the Soviet Union was developing several new long-range missiles in addition to four missiles that it had been testing with multiple warheads.

Martin, United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, asked today for Congressional approval of the Nixon Administration's request for $750-million in economic aid for the Saigon Government so that "in a very few years we will be able to regard our Vietnam involvement as closed." Negotiations for associate membership in the European Economic Community for 44 Caribbean, African and Pacific nations opened here today with E.E.C. in open disagreement on two of the major issues - sugar and energy.

A Queens firm accused of misleading Spanish-speaking married couples into believing they could get divorces in 24 hours has been charged with violating the Consumer protection Law, Consumer Affairs Commissioner Elinor Guggenheimer announced. She said the Latinoamerica Company, 41-12 102d Street, Corona, had advertised in a Spanish magazine that it could get "divorcio en 24 horas."

A bill that would Impose strict Federal environmental controls on the widespread desolation of land and water caused by strip mining for coal cleared the House tonight after one of the chamber's longest and most heated debates in years.

Yesterday's Supreme Court [ruling all but barring the busing of school children across school district lines to achieve -desegregation adds a major new legal barrier to the already potent political and social forces working against the integration of big-city schools.

An appeals court today reversed a Municipal Court conviction of a man charged with disrupting a public meeting. The only think the man did, the court noted, was call a Hudson County Freeholder a crook.
Mayor Beame yesterday proposed a requirement that there be an "annual inventory of cash and securities" owned by the city, to be done by an outside auditor.

A man who has waited 15 months in the Brooklyn House of Detention without going to trial on a murder charge was the first witness yesterday at the civil trial of a prisoners' suit against major figures running the Brooklyn criminaljustice system.

Carl Yastrzemski hit the 300th home run of his career last night in Tiger Stadium, one of three homers hit by the Red Sox in a 12-4 victory over slumping Detroit.

Patricia Endress, who was dismissed as an assistant professor of journalism at Brookdale Community College in Lincroft after the student newspaper published conflict-of-interest charges against the college's board chairman, ha filed suit to he reinstated.

The House Judiciary Committee's impeachment debate will be telecast today by NBC-TV and the Public Broadcasting Service, starting at 10 A.M. The three networks are rotating in covering the proceedings.
The financial condition of the beleaguered Franklin National Bank continued to deteriorate during the week ended Wednesday, as the bank lost an additional $86-million in deposits.

The conflict between the Ko. rean Roman Catholic Church and President Park Chung Hee's Government intensified today when over 2,000 Catholics gathered at a mass to protest the jailing of a prominent Bishop.
George D. Ford, whose father operated the Washington theater where Abraham Lincoln was assassinated, died Wednesday in a hospital here. He was 94 years old.

A court reporter from California, testified today in the perjury trial of Lieut. Gov. Ed Reinecke of California that he had found substantial errors in the transcript of a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on which the indictment of Mr. Reinecke is based.

Dr. Max Levin, former neurologist at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals and clinical professor of neurology at New York Medical College, died here Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 73 years old and lived at 350 Central Park West.

The House Public Works Committee defied the Nixon Administration today by voting out a $20-billion mass transit bill that would provide operating and capital funds for six years.

ESB, Inc., may not be the sexiest of corporate names and neither was its predecessor name, the Electric Storage Battery Company. Production of auto batteries in the new ESB plant in Burlington, Iowa. Concern is focus of acquisition fight.
Claire Potter of Claire Walson interior decorators at 37 West 57th Street, died here Wednesday. She was 82 years old and lived at 7 West 77th Street.

The Canadian contingent with the United Nations peace-keeping force in Cyprus is to be almost doubled, from 486 to about 950 men, the Secretary of State for External Affairs, Mitchell W. Sharp, announced today.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi accused her critics today of spreading "McCarthyism" in India by making wild allegations of corruption against her and her Government leaders.

Four persons were killed today when two single-engine airplanes collided in the air. Ken Still, happily recovered from a stiff neck that sidelined him for seven weeks, shot a five- under-par 65 today to lead the first round of the $200,000 Canadian open.

President Nixon's popularity rating has declined to its lowest point recorded to date, with only 24 per cent approving his performance, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

Doug Stein, who won the 1972 Ivy League golf championship when he was captain of Columbia, took the medal today in the Metropolitan Golf Association's 72d amateur tournament at the Sunningdale Country Club.

Large profit increases continued to be reported by oil companies for the second quarter this year. Texaco, Inc., ranking second in the industry after the Exxon Corporation, reported yesterday a 72.1 per cent rise in the June-quarter profit, while Sun Oil Company's earnings climbed 163 per cent.

French participants in the Franco-American exploration of the submarine rift valley that bisects the Atlantic Ocean believe they have discovered a geyser whose eruptions generate almost pure manganese ore.

For the second time in five days, Assemblyman Arthur JKremer has been cleared by a Nassau County grand jury of allegations of wrongdoing. Willian Cahn the Nassau District Attorney, announced today that the grand jury had voted to close its investigation into charger that the legislator had promised the Long Beach city police a pay raise in return for their support of Democratic candidates in last year's elections.

Steel production for the week ended July 27 slipped by 1 per cent to 2,758,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was the low point for the year to date and compared with the 2,786,000 tons poured in the preceding week.

A state agency called today for postponement of construction of all health-care facilities in the Newark area, including the proposed New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry, because "the absence of proper planning" could skyrocket hospital costs.

A robbery case manufactured by the office of the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, served to uncover a "virtual cesspool of corruption" in the Brooklyn criminal justice system, one of Mr. Nadjari's associates said in court papers filed recently.

Cowboys of the world - beef seems to be taking a modest place next to oil as one of the latest sources of international trouble, and like oil, it cuts across all other divisions. Meat processing at Rungis, major food market in Paris. It has been reported that the Soviet Union was buying Western European beef well below the world price.

Members of the House Judiciary Committee have been eloquent in conveying their sense of agony and awe at the decisions which chance has called upon them to make this summer of 1974. Less evident, but equally justified, is the sense of confidence among legislators and the observing public alike over the way this solemn and fateful political process is operating within the democratic structure.

Don't be surprised if the New York Giants punt the ball toward the sideline instead-of high, deep and down the middle in their exhibition opener Saturday night at the Astrodome against the Houston Oilers.

The Nixon Administration, with the stated purpose of winning bigger and faster rate increases for utility companies, has called a national conference of the state agencies that regulate the utilities.

Federal Energy Administrator John C. Sawhill urged the governors of the energyrich Western states today to overcome their fears of rigid Federal regulation and to support the Administration's package of energy bills.

Harold A. Lett, a leader in race relations in New Jersey since 1934, died Thursday in the Theresa Grotta Center for Restorative Services in West Caldwell, N. J. He was 78 years old and a former resident of Newark. Harold A. Lett

The American Dance Festival, in its 27th season, has also been the scene of an experimental theater festival. During the last month, seven prominent New York experimental companies have been in rotating residence with plays, work shops and special, events for children.

District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan and Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm accompanied a group of assistant district attorneys on a visit to the Manhattan Men's House of Detention yesterday to show them the improvements being made under court pressure. Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm, left, and Manhattan District Attorney Richard H. Kuh inspecting recreation area being built on the Tombs roof, during tour.

The deputy White Plains corporation counsel issued a legal opinion yesterday that effectively prevented the Common Council from electing a successor to Mayor Carl J. Delfino, who resigned four days before his death on July 21.

Erich Kaestner, one of Germany's best-known authors, died in hospital here today. He was 75 years old. Mr. Kaestner's most famous work was a children's story, "Emil and the Detectives," which was translated into 24 languages and filmed.

A Federal grand jury refused today to vote an indictment that was specially drawn by Department of Justice officials in Washington with the intention of excluding Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive industrialist, from a list of defendants.

The state's second-highest court ruled today that the courts, rather than the State Commissioner of Education, should decide whether a dispute between a school board and a teachers' group was subject to arbitration.
The Foreign Ministers of Britain, Greece and Turkey recessed tonight after 31 hours of almost continuous negotiations without reaching agreement on a Cyprus cease-fire.

A detailed proposal that could form the basis for coordinated trading of options on both the American Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange was distributed to American Exchange members, the Amex's chairman, Paul Kolton, announced yesterday.

Previewing his contest for a full four-year term, Governor p Wilson indicated yesterday that a his campaign would be less expensive, less colorful and shorter than what many politicians consider to be the classic campaigns of his predecessor, Nelson A. Rockefeller. Governor Wilson as he was interviewed here.

Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons announced that it was setting up a $2.6-million clinical-research center for muscular dystrophy and related diseases. The center will be financed in part by a $1.5million construction and research grant from the Muscular Dystrophy Association of America, which is establishing clinical-research centers in four universities in the country.

Christi Pastore wanted to join the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour six years ago, but she was pregnant. She was pregnant again the next year, too. Then there were the diaper years that followed when she could manage only to play a few weekday rounds at her home club, Beaver Brook in Clinton. N .I.

Pilobolus was originally a clutch of muscular young men who descended from Dartmouth several seasons ago to astonish us with their powerful gymnastic grace. Last year the group added two women and seemed slightly baffled about what to. do with them artistically. Last evening Alison Chase and Martha Clarke took a giant creative step forward with the company in the premiere of "Monkshood's Delight" at Connecticut College's American Dance Festival.

Truman Bradley, Chicago broadcast announcer who also appeared in films and was host of a television series, died yesterday at the age of 69. Among Mr. Bradley's movie credits was "Northwest Passage." He was host of the television series "Science Fiction Theater" for several years.

Hoping to head off what could become a stampede for impeachment, the House minority leader, Representative John J. Rhodes of Arizona, is to announce later this week a plan to hold informal "rap sessions" for Republicans to debate the issue. John J. Rhodes

Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso said today that because of community opposition, the county would not sell 10 acres of land it owns in Lawrence, L. I., for a proposed new hospital site. The site was intended to be used for the new Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center's South Shore division.
Mike Adamle, the thirdleading rusher with the New York Jets last season, reported to camp today and became the eighth established player on the club to cross the Player's Association picket line.

David J. Bardin, the State Environmental Proteotion Commissioner, proposed today new quality standards for New Jersey waterways. The standards, revised for the first time in three years, are intended to be a guide to managing the quality of lakes, rivers and coastal areas.
An Arab League conference, which opened today at the Lebanese summer resort of Aleih, is reappraising the effectiveness of the Arab economic boycott against Israel.

Earl M. Crittenden, former state Republican chairman from Orlando, and two Federal housing officials pleaded not guilty today to conspiracy charges in connection with an influence-peddling case involving Senator Edward Gurney, Republican of Florida.
Soviet scientists report they have prepared a seismic map of the Balkans with which it will be possible to estimate the relative degree of earthquake risk anywhere in the area.

A priest died and more than a dozen others were rescued by firemen using aerial ladders and the platforms of tower ladders, last night, when a threealarm fire of suspicious origin erupted in the priory of St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church, at Lexington Avenue and 65th Street.

A major New York builder announced yesterday intentions to construct thousands of apartments on two large Hudson River waterfront parcels in Manhattan that the builder has agreed to purchase from the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company for more than, $100-million.

Vice President Gerald R. Ford says in an interview in Dun's Review: "I am worried about interest rates. I hope that the Federal Reserve, once it sees that there is an honest-to-goodness effort being made in fiscal policy, will not be too tough too long." Diana K. Mayer

One side effect of the current inflation is a modest penny-pinching among members of the middle class who are too affluent to cry, yet vulnerable enough to feel some pain. Interviews with about 40 persons in the metropolitan area disclosed that while few of them could cite Consumer Price Index figures, most were disturbed by rising costs.

With Aqueduct idle, Monmouth Park rolled out a green carpet of welcome for New York horseplayers today in the form of its biggest daily double in 22 years. The payoff was $3,417,60 for $2.

Two Soviet chess grandmasters, Anatoly Karpov and Viktor Korchnoi, will begin a series of games here Sept. 16 to determine which of them will face the world champion, Bobby Fischer of the United States, in June, 1975, chess officials announced tonight.
The Senate Finance Committee made substantial changes during a closed-door session today on the controversial House-passed trade bill the Administration wants approved this year.

Several leading brokerage firms that broke industry ranks early this month and raised commission rates that they charge banks, mutual funds, insurance companies and other big institutional customers are now rolling back the increases. The rates affected applied to transactions of $2,000 to $300,000 and covered the bulk of institutional trading.

Vice President Ford said today that John B. Connally's political future would depend on what happened at his trial. "I have highly respected John Connally as Secretary of the Navy under President Kennedy and as Secretary of the Treasury under President Nixon," Mr. Ford told a news conference.

The Government today ordered special emergency panels to investigate prison strife as the death toll rose to four in 10 days of rioting in 43 of 170 French prisons.

After suffering several reverses in the southern part of the country in recent months, Communist troops have dug in and inflicted extensive casualties in some of the hardest fighting since the ceasefire went into effect in January, 1973.

One of 11 women ordained yesterday in Philadelphia as Episcopal priests preparing to give communion. At rear is Bishop Daniel Corrigan of Denver, who supervised.

Prime Minister Norman Kirk said today he had reason to believe France had exploded another nuclear bomb in the atmosphere at her Mururoa atoll test site in the South Pacific.

Shareholders of Atlantic Department Stores, Inc., will meet in special session today to vote on a merger plan. Its approval is a foregone conclusion. Arlen Realty and Development, through a subsidiary, already owns twothirds of the 1.5 million Atlantic shares outstanding, and the Arlen shares will be voted for the merger plan.

A worker at a cigarette factory in Bristol was slightly injured today when she opened a package containing an incendiary device, the police said. They said the device, in a packagee mailed from Northern Ireland, caused a small fire.
Vice President Ford defended his civil rights record today and said that opposition to him by leaders in the field had caused him to pay more attention to the issue.

John L. Julian, wno was cmer floor broker on the American Stock Exchange for Merrill Lynch. Pierce, Fenner Smith until his retirement in 1958, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived here.

Walter Browne held the pace as leader in the United States championship at the LaSalle Hotel in Chicago after 10 rounds of play. By brilliantly defeating Arthur Bisguier's Petrov Defense in Round 9 and drawing with Pal Benko in the 10th round, the 25-year-old American grandmaster amassed 8 points.
Hershel Anderson of Tracy City, Tenn., won the center-fire pistol competition today with a score of 874 of 900 to take the two-day lead in the 1974 National pistol shooting championships.

The Chrysler Corporation reported today earnings of $27.8-million in the second quarter, down 74 per cent from a year ago but a marked improvement from the 98 per cent drop registered in the first quarter.

John M. Bailey of Hartford, who served as Democratic national chairman in the administrations of President John F. Kennedy and President Lyndon B. Johnson, was re-elected by acclamation tonight to a 15th two-year term as Connecticut Democratic chairman.

Angel Oquendo, left, and Jorge Ahumada in the fourth round of their bout

Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. said today that he had stayed a New Orleans court's ban on reporting certain parts of a pretrial hearing in a rape-murder case there because he believed the order was an unconstitutional prior restraint of publication.

Those convenience dinner mixes such as Hamburger Helper that the instant food industry is pushing with such zeal are giving homemakers somewhat of a windfall these days: After dinner, there's only one pot to wash.

In some sections of Idaho, bumper potato crops have sent farmers and their wives on a jewelry-buying binge. They have been buying 1carat and I1/2-carat diamond rings at $3,000 to $8,000. The National Jewelry Trade Show started yesterday. Exhibitors and buyers, like those above, were at the New York Hilton and the Americana. Watches were staples. Gold coins on chains were also prominent.

Machine-gun fire and explosions were heard in many parts of Beirut tonight as supporters of a right-wing Lebanese political party and Palestinian guerrillas engaged in a fierce 90-minute battle northcast of the city.
A jury of 11 men and one woman was selected in Brooklyn yesterday in the trial of State Supreme Court Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi, who is charged with perjury and obstruction of justice.

Rod Laver is returning to competition. After an 11week layoff, the Aussie lefthander will celebrate his 36th birthday by playing in the $50,000 Volvo international tournament beginning Aug. 5 at Bretton Woods, N.H.

Dr. Albert J. Brinz, a 50year-old physician from Scarsdale, N.Y.., was indicted in Federal District Court here yesterday on charges that he had submitted 15 false Medicare claims for a total of almost S6.00D.

Archbishop Makarios conferred with Secretary of State Kissinger for more than an hour today and concluded that "the role of the United States is really very constructive" in efforts to obtain a settlement of the Cyprus issue.

A Philadelphia man was found not guilty of murder yesterday in the 1972 death of Martin Allan Hess, whose car was dynamited outside a fashionable apartment house in Cherry Hill, near Camden. The prosecution had charged unsuccessfully that the defendant, Anthony DiPasquale, 33 years old, was a "contract" killer who was paid $15,000 to murder Mr. Hess. Mr. Hess had been scheduled to testify in a narcotics case.

A Federal grand jury refused today to vote an indictment that was specially drawn by Department of Justice officials in Washington with the intention of excluding Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive industrialist, from a list of defendants.

With a summit meeting of Soviet and East European Communist party leaders apparently imminent, the Soviet party newspaper Pravda today denounced part of the Western press as trying S to drive a wedge between Moscow and Rumania.
A Federal judge ruled today that the Navy must release a sailor from activereserve drills because 'a recruiter's promise of technical training was not fulfilled.
The State Assembly today approved by a 75-to-1 vote a $200-million Green Acres bond issue, the largest in the state's history, for acquisition and development of parks and recreation lands.

The Department of Defense is scheduled to give the Fairchild Republic Company final approval to start production on 30 A-10 close air support planes for the Air Force, informed sources disclosed today. A-10 close-support fighter. Fairchild Republic is to be given authorization to start building 30 of these jet planes.

Saudi Arabia will auction off a 16-month supply of 1.5 million barrels of oil a day at whatever price the market will bear, the Middle East Economic Survey, a highly reliable journal published in Beirut, Lebanon, reported yesterday.

Bernard F. Agnelli, senior vice president and manager of the New York office of Dialog, the public-relations arm of the J. Walter Thompson Company, lied Saturday of a heart attack near Kingston, N. Y., while jogging. He was 43 years old and lived at 45-12 244th Street, Douglaston, Queens.

DISCREET CHARMS "L'Age d'Or," released in 1930, was Luis Bunuel's second film, and yet its sardonic tone and surreal hijinks offer an amazing demonstration of the continuity that has marked Mr. Bunuel's long, productive career. It's considered a classic film, one of Mr. Bunuel's most important, but it is also seldom seen here because the producer, Viscount Charles de Noailles, has been reluctant to have prints sent out here and there.

The State Department announced today it had suspended negotiations on establishing diplomatic relations with East Germany because of interference with traffic on the highway access routes through East Germany to West Berlin.

The Assembly gave final legislative approval tonight, after a long I and often emotional debate, to a bill that would give hospitals and individuals the right to refuse to perform or assist in abortions without fear of legal I or disciplinary action.
Lieut. Gov. Ed Reinecke or California, convicted last Saturday on Federal perjury charges, said today that he would not resign unless legally required to do so.
A $22.2-billion authorization for weapons,. military research and related expenditures was passed today by a 305-to-38 vote in the House and was sent to the Senate.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is having attack dogs trained to chase vandals who paint graffiti on subway cars in the outdoor storage yards of the subway system. Jerry Baumann, left, and Rick Robins training a dog for guard duty to prevent the daubing of subway trains as shown below. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to use 10 such dogs, on leashes, at five yards.

Representatives of the striking National Football League Players Association met for 80 minutes with a Federal mediator today but little was said about what went on behind the closed doors.

Vice Adm. Harry Manning, who commanded the superliner United States on her record-breaking maiden voyage across the Atlantic, died yesterday at his home, 183 Chestnut Ridge Road, Saddle River, N.J. He was 77 years old.

Ildebrando Cardinal Antoniutti, a former papal diplomat, died today in an automobile accident near Bologna, the Vatican announced today. He was 75 years old. Cardinal Antoniutti was considered a traditionalist and was one of the most prominent figures in Vatican diplomacy.

William E. Colby, Director of Central Intelligence, said in Congressional testimony made public today that, contrary to Pentagon concern, the Soviet Union was unlikely to build up its Indian Ocean fleet significantly unless the United States built up its fleet there first.
