The Public Service Commission yesterday authorized the Consolidated Edison Company to increase gas rates by $31.3-million, or an average of 19.5 per cent, for its 1,187,000 customers in Manhattan, the Bronx and parts of Queens and Westchester County. The minimum monthly charge, which covers the first 300 cubic feet of gas used, will rise by 54 cents.

President Idi Amin, who ordered his Soviet-equipped army and air force on full alert yesterday, called off a threatened invasion of Tanzania today.

The Treasury Department yesterday put a 9 per cent interest rate on $4-billion of notes it plans to sell to investors next week. The rate is the highest on such a financing in the country's history for Treasury securities with maturities of more than one year.

WEST CALDWELL, Aug. 2-Albert Cicerone, who has retired from the Prudential Insurance Company, has slowed down to a walk. The former five-time national heel-and-toe walking champion now does his rapid strolling as a hobby, but is enjoying it just as much as he did when he was a fierce competitor from 1931 to 1952.

The United States Court of Appeals today ordered a new trial for former Maryland Senator Daniel B. Brewster, who was found guilty almost two years ago of accepting an illegal gratuity to influence his Senate vote on postal-rate legislation.

LONDON, Aug. 2 (AP)-Cyril Smith, a British concert pianist who overcame paralysis to make a professional comeback, died of a heart attack today. He was 65 years old. Mr. Smith lost the use of his left arm after a stroke in 1956.

The House Ways and Means Committee completed work today on the first draft of a major revision of the tax laws, after first voting to incorporate in its bill a new version of legislation it had approved earlier increasing the taxes of the oil industry.

Taggart D. Adams was appointed yesterday as chief of the civil division in the United States Attorney's office. Mr. Adams, who is 33 years old and lives in Manhattan, has been an assistant United States attorney for three years.

President Luis Eche verria Alvarez today ordered the Attorney General's department to investigate whether there are agents of the United States Central Intelligence Agency in the Government, a spokesman said.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP)-The Federal Trade Commission has dropped a request for an injunction against the Real Lemon division of Borden, Inc., that would have forced the company to charge uniform prices in different parts of the nation. The suit filed in the United States District Court was dropped in favor of pursuing "the normal procedures of antitrust action" against the company, an F.T.C. spokesman said.

Some borrowers, the biggest or those who can pay the highest rates, can get all the credit they need, while other borrowers are cut off and threatened with financial disaster. Obviously, it is impossible to run a generally restrictive monetary policy without hurting anybody;

The Federal Trade Commission reported today cigarette sales in 1973 increased 4 per cent over the previous year, the largest rise in 10 years. More significantly, it said, the sale of low-tar cigarettes rose 40 per cent in the same period.

Margaret McKellar, executive secretary of the Whitney Museum of American Art, died Monday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L.I. She was 62 years old and lived at 17 Roxbury Road in Garden City, L.I.

Secretary of the Treasury William E, Simon said today that oil company profits were not so high as they seemed but had been "obscured by a smokescreen of hyperbole and demagoguery-from both sides."

The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday an operating loss of $305,000 for the second quarter and a firsthalf loss of $218,000. It lost $615,000 in the quarter a year ago and $722,000 in the first half.

Edward Gudeman, an investment banker who was Under Secretary of Commerce in the Administration of President Kennedy, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla.

Operation Push in New Jersey charged today that this town's administration was continuing to discriminate against people of minority groups in the Police and Fire Departments despite an order by the State Civil Rights Division to end the bias.

Representative Hugh L. Carey has borrowed so heavily from his brother to finance his gubernatorial campaign that he must repay at least $120,000 of the loans or risk violating the new state election law. The law limits loans and contributions by a candidate and his family.
Russ' Stewart, a retired vice president of Field Enterprises, Inc., of Chicago drowned yesterday while fishing near his home, here. He was 65 years old.
Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today the price of gasoline could soon drop six or seven cents a gallon, under certain conditions.
Carmen Salvino of Chicago, wrapped up first place in the $50,000 New Jersey open bowling tournament tonight, defeating Don McCune of Munster, Ind., 208192, in the final match.

The Senate passed a bill today that would exempt staterun lotteries from the 10 per cent excise tax on wagers. Struck from the bill by voice vote was a provision to require a 20 per cent Federal income tax withholding from state lottery winnings.

A White House conference called to encourage state utility commissions to give swift rate increases to power companies was postponed today, in part because officials felt that the conference would appears to conflict with President in Ford's fight against inflation.

Ten street-corner hot-dog venders came to City Hall yesterday to thank Mayor Beame personally for interceding with the Police Department in their behalf.

A 35-man police force and two Government officials of the Netherlands Antilles flew today from Curacao to the island of St. Martin, where the Dutch Government building was burned to the ground in suspected arson.

The Procter Gamble Company, a leading manufacturer of soap, detergents, toiletries, food and paper products, posted record results for the fourth quarter and year ended June 0, the company announced yesterday.

Less than a day after President Ford's charge to Congress to "avoid unwarranted cuts in national defense," two Senate committees have moved separately to reduce American military spending and foreign aid by almost $6-billion.

Efforts to reach a compromise between Congress and the Executive branch on the tangled question of the emigration of Soviet Jews and passage of the trade bill have entered a decisive phase, with President Ford possibly ready to enter the discussions directly, Congressional aides said today.
The Cyprus peace talks broke down here early this morning, creating the threat of a new outbreak of fighting between Greek Cypriote and Turkish troops on the Island.

With a room and a roar, 200 motorcyclists from across the state converged on the capital today to demand that Governor Byrne sign a bill passed by the Legislature in mid-May that would permit motorcycles to operate on the Garden State Parkway north of Ocean County.

Emperor Haile Selassie's personal treasurer, Bltta Admassu Retta, has surrendered to the armed forces, it was announced today. He is the second of two high-ranking palace official named by the armed forces last week as wanted men.

Legislation that a Department of Transportation official described as "a disaster" for highway beautification efforts and as "a sellout" to the billboard industry is expected to be reported out of the House Public Works Committee in the next few days.

The Wounded Knee trial was recessed today to allow a defendant, Dennis Banks to travel to Kenora, Ont., to prevent a potentially bloody confrontation between Canadian officials and Indians holding a park.

Sixty-one job-hunting Ecuadorians who had stowed away in refrigerated holds were taken into custody yesterday when the Prudential Lines' Santa Elena docked in Brooklyn from South America-the largest number of stowaways that immigration and customs officials could ever remember on a single ship in at least 30 years.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, won a court ruling today in a battle over a bill that he said former President Nixon had illegally attempted to pocket-veto.

A Hyattsville, Md., woman who was wounded by a bullet in the attack on Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama in 1972 has been awarded $2,376 in damaged by the Maryland Criminal Injuries Compensation Board. She is Dora Thompson, 36 years old, a Wallace campaign worker.

The performances Tuesday evening at the Mostly Mozart concert in Avery Fisher Hall were solid, decently effective statements of a stimulating mix of chamber and solopiano pieces by Mozart, Havdn and Schubert.

President Ford turned his attention largely to international affairs today for the first time since taking office on Friday. He stayed in close touch with Secretary of State Kissinger on developments on Cyprus and talked by- telephone with the British Foreign Secretary, James Callaghan, and Prime Minister Harold Wilson.

Volkswagenwerk, A.G., reported today in a letter to stockholders that its group loss in the first quarter, reported in May to be about $34-million, increased in the second quarter. No figures were given.
An unknown assailant tried to assassinate President Park Chung Hee of South Korea this morning as he delivered a national day address. The President was not hurt.

Peter Selz, professor of art history at the University of California at Berkeley and former director of the university's art museum, testified yesterday in Surrogate's Court that the 100 paintings by Mark Rothko bought by the Marlborough Gallery for $1.8-million were worth $4,038,000 when purchased in May, 1970.

Customer margin accounts were in slightly better shape at the end of July. a month earlier, but a continued weak market threatens to trigger numerous margin calls, which in turn could depress stock prices below their present low level ls.

Former President Richard M. Nixon has been taking drives every day this week to a heavily guarded and deserted beach at the Camp Pendleton marine base 13 miles south of his San Clemente estate, while the general public is being welcomed back to the beach that, at times, he alone had been permitted to use.

Jack McKeon, manager of the Kansas City Royals, was miffed when he learned that the Oakland A's had begun accepting ticket orders for the American League playoffs. "Maybe we ought to start selling tickets, too," he said.

An error-filled boxing comedy in which no one got hurt but everyone was embarrassed ended yesterday when the State Athletic Commission formally called off next Monday's bout involving the world lightweight champion, Roberto Duran.

Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin accused the Food and Drug Administration today of trying to assume too much power with proposed controls over vitamins. The agency in turn predicted there would be widespread consumer fraud and unchecked quackery unless its new regulations went into effect on the first of next year as scheduled.

Argentine Army units pursued Marxist guerrillas into the mountains near Tucumaan Province today in a drive to wipe out a highly organized band. The fighting marked the first time the army was authorized to join the police against guerrillas since a civilian Government came to power last year after 'seven years of military control.
If there are two nonproductive traits that the experienced angler exhibits most often, they are stubbornness and the failure to experiment.
Dr. Edward M. Westburgh, a clinical psychologist and management consultant, died Friday in Holderness, N. H. He was 75 years old and lived in West Hartford, Conn.

Brinegar urged Congress to make localities assume greater responsibility for financing transit operations and Republican Congressmen fought to cut a $20-billion mass-transit bill in half..
Premier Bulent Ecevit said today that Turkey's military action on Cyprus was a continuation of the one halted on July 30 after the signing of the Geneva agreement.

Four Episcopalian Bishops who participated in the ordination of 11 women into the priesthood of their church three weeks ago in Philadelphia explained and defended their actions before the House of Bishops here today.

Fighting in Cyprus took President Ford's attention away from the vacant Vice-Presidency today and might delay his choice of a successor in that job, according to the White House.

A Venezuelan airliner crashed today into a hill on the Caribbean island of Margarita during a torrential rain storm, killing 47 of the 48 people on board. The four-engine turboprop plane of the state-owned airline Aeropostal was on a flight from Caracas to the island, a tourist center 220 miles northeast of here.
State Supreme Court Justice Leonard Rubenfeld has ruled unconstitutional a provision of the state election law on residency requirements for voting in primary elections.

WASHINGTON-In Cottondale, Ala., I. Willis Russell, professor emeritus of the University of 'Alabama, sifts through newspapers and magazines looking for new words, or new uses of old words. He is the dean of America's word-watchers.

Home Box Office, Inc. the pay-television service that will be offered on the Manhattan Cable System this fall, yesterday defended its right to carry occasional games of the New york Yankees as "consistent With the spirit and intent" of the Federal Communications Commission's pay-cable policies.

Consistency and competitiveness are the trademarks of Bill Scarlett's success in tennis. Scarlett has won the New Jersey state men's 35-yearsand-over singles championship for four straight years. His last victory came last month when he defeated Tony Fusco, 5-7, 6-2, 6-1, to win the title at the Upper Ridgewood Tennis Club.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half.The company also announced an increased quarterly dividend of 38 cents a share payable Oct. 1 to stockholders of record Aug. 23.

A State Supreme Court jury of 10 men and two women has found a 29-year-old man guilty on one count of murder in the slaying of a 20-year-old Harlem man almost two years ago.
Governor Byrne and about 40 legis lators, many of them accompanied by their wives and children, toured South Jersey today to study the problems of the area's farms.

Greece withdrew her armed force's from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today, blaming her allies for not having prevented Turkey's new military advances in Cyprus.

Fifty-eight Ecuadorians who stowed away to the United States in search of jobs and a better future went home yesterday, in the cabin of a jet airliner instead of the dank holds of a cargo ship, and eating sirloin steak instead of green bananas.

Iran has offered to lend money to the Grumman Corporation to enable it to continue production of the controversial F-14 fighter plane, Representative Otis G. Pike of Long Island disclosed yesterday. Iran has 80 F-14's on order.

A man who wandered into a Sheepshead Bay courtyard bleeding from a stomach wound late Tuesday night, asked stoop sitters for help and then begged them not to call the police may may be the latest Casualty of a Mafia war, the police and other law enforcement sources said yesterday.

The Marine Midland Bank, New York, has been authorized by the Federal Reserve Board to raise its participation in the capital of the Paris-based merchant bank Interunion-Banque, S. A. to 45 per cent from 19.4 per cent, Interunion-Banque said today.

United States auto makers reported today record sales of 207,624 new cars in early August, with the gain attributed in part to buyers who were seeking to avoid large price increases scheduled for 1975 models.

Israeli troops shelled areas of southern Lebanon today, residents said, two days after Palestinian guerrillas reortedly withdrew from the area. Only crops were damaged in the shelling of Racshaya Fukhar and Kfar Shuba, village in the Arkub area, the residents said.

In their first comment on the city's new plan to meet cleanair standards, Federal officials said yesterday that the plan had -- as one of them put it "a lot of good concepts," but that it was deficient in not detailing how these concepts would be realized or where the needed money would come from.

President Ford reportedly plans to recruit the public information director of the Justice Department, John W. Hushen, as the top assistant to his press secretary, J. F. terHorst. Mr. Hushen turned aside questions by reporters today.
Led by a sharp increase in the price of meat, food prices rose 0.2 per cent last week, according to the Department of Consumer of Affairs.

The Appelate Division of Superior Court today upheld a five-count indictment charging four Riverside men with conspiracy to bribe two public officials in an attempt to "influence their behavior in office."

The United States exploded a nuclear device in the Nevada desert today, its third announced weapons-related the this year, the Atomic Energy Commission said. A Spokesman said that the blast was in a yield range equivalent to less than 20,000 tons of TNT.

When Al Carmines, the composer and author of a long list of successful Off Broadway musicals who is also a minister of the Judson Memorial Church, gives his occasional concerts or makes his even more occasional nightclub appearances, his programs are usually drawn from the wealth of varied, provocative and witty material he has written for his shows.
Stock prices dropped for the fifth day in a row yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to its lowest point in nearly four years.
Turkish forces, which began a heavy air and ground attack early yesterday, appeared today to be on their way toward seizing control of much of orthern Cyprus.
Gimbel Brothers, Inc., which operates 67 department stores including the Saks Fifth Avenue specialty stores, more than doubled its earnings in the third quarter ended June 30, it said yesterday.
The draw for post positions for the Cane at Yonkers Raceway Saturday night was held today and when the entry box was emptied, 14 horses were entered and officials began to worry.

The Parsippany-Troy Hills Township Council today ordered the huge Joint-in-the-woods nightclub to close for 15 days for failure to advise the township of a "change of facts" following the club's application for a liquor license.

Outdoor programs seldom come as imaginatively planned as that led by Arthur Bloom in Washington Square Park on Tuesday night. He used an ensemble of brass and percussion players, not too different from the small bands to be found performing in village squares.
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization called on Greece today to reconsider "as soon as possible" her decision to withdraw her armed forces from the 15-nation Western defense alliance.
The World Bank announced today that it had borrowed $500-million in Venezuela at 8 per cent interest, the largest single borrowing operation ever undertaken by the development institution.

New York City's hope of saving the 35-cent transit fare was doubly jolted today as Transportation Secretary Claude S. Brinegar urged Congress to make localities assume greater responsibility for financing transit operations and Republican Congressmen fought to cut' a $20-billion mass-transit bill in half.

Stocks continued to fall yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, closing sharply lower in light trading, as Wall Street turned nervous reports of renewed fighting in Cyprus and as the pall of inflation and high interest rates continued unabated.

Sandman Jr. David Norcross, executive director of the commission, said in Trenton that the agency was looking into a loan to the committee by the Livingston National Bank on Nov. 1, 1973, only days be'fore the Democratic candidate,

Anne Quast Sander, a three-time winner, relied on her putter today for another easy victory, while Carol Semple, the defending champion, was pushed to the final hole before gaining the thirdround final of the United States women's amateur golf championships.

The tape recordings that for mer President Nixon made of thousands of hours of conversations with aides, associates and advisers are his personal property and will -be returned to his control, a White House spokesman said today.

David Livingstone was one of those men that only a powerful faith can produce. He traversed some 30,000 miles in Africa, much of it on foot. At one time, while crossing an immense swamp, he and his party had to build mud piles, "like graves," to sleep on each night.
Robert L. Stanfield, leader of the parliamentary opposition, announced today that he intended to resign as head of the Progressive Conservative party and would not run in the next federal election.
Before he resigned as President last week, Richard M. Nixon ordered his aides not to seek any deals preventing his future prosecution, The Baltimore Sun said today.

Records of three drug rehalilitation programs and two school-based prevention centers have been referred to government authorities for the investigation of possible fraudulent activities, sources within the city's Addiction Services Agency have disclosed.

Last December, Cavenham, Ltd., a British food manufacturer and retailer, acquired 51 per cent of the Grand Union Company, the big American supermarket chain. Last April, James Wood, deputy managing director of Cavenham, became president of Grand Union. And last week, Mr. Wood took on the additional title of chief executive officer.
A 14-year-old robber was shot by one of his intended victims during a holdup attempt in Brooklyn Tuesday night, the police said, and died with an unloaded pistol in his hand.
Representative James J. Howard, Democrat of New Jersey', charged today that the nation's major oil companies had cut back gasoline production to maintain gasoline prices.

District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan issued a long-awaited directive to his 200 assistants yesterday that prohibits plea bargaining in cases involving "particularly egregious, heinous or notorious criminal conduct" and places tight restrictions on its use in other cases.

The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that the opposing sides in the Cyprus conflict had agreed to make the Hilton and Cleopatra Hotels and the Kibis clinic in Nicosia "safety zones" for civilians.
A report issued today by the Hudson County chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union and students from Jersey City State College urged the city administration "never to reopen the municipal jail.
Lynn Marie Haney and Peter Duncan Burchard, both writers, were married at noon yesterday in the United Church of Christ of Stonington, Conn. The Rev. Frederick Sherwood Lowry performed the ceremony.

Leftover buying orders from Tuesday pushed prices of wheat, soybeans and corn up their daily limits at the opening of trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Then prices of wheat and soybeans dropped quite sharply in a rush of selling, but corn stayed up the limit.

Harold G. Brown, a retired New York stockbroker, died yesterday in Princeton (N.J.) Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived near Lambertville, N. J.
William McKinley Keller, retired, president of the Association of American Railroads, died Sunday at Lankenau Hospital in Overbrook, Pa. He was 72 years old and lived in Wynnewood, Pa.

Congress moved swiftly today to act on President Ford's request for a new "cost of living task force" to keep watch over private wage and price behavior but without authority for mandatory controls.
An 8-year-old Coney Island boy was killed and four other boys were injured last night when a soda bottle filled with dry ice exploded in the air, the police said.
An unknown as sailant tried to assassinate President Park Chung Hee of South Korea this morning as he delivered a national day address. The President was not hurt.

A Federal appeals court proposed yesterday that the city grant the requests of inmates No want to be transferred from the Manhattan House of detentionn for Men to improved facilities on Rikers Island.

When it comes to artistry and craftsmanship, anyone who wants to see the difference between articles made in Hong Kong and those created in mainland China can wander through Asian House, a handsome, balconied new furniture store Seventh Avenue at 56th Street.

A precedent in private commercial arbitration was set yesterday when a three - man panel, hearing a dispute between William Safire, author and columnist, and his former publisher, William Morrow Co., opened the hearings at 340 West 51st Street to the press.

Experts have divided opinions about one not-uncommon situation in bidding: if it becomes clear at a low level that game must be reached, is a raise to game weaker or stronger than a raise short of game?

Dr. Bert James Loewenberg, a well-known Darwin scholar and a member of the Sarah Lawrence College history faculty from 1942 to his retirement in 1971, died Tuesday at his home in Orange, Conn. His age was 69.

Turkish forces, which began heavy air and ground attacks, seem headed for control of much of northern Cyprus, as armored columns approached the eastern coastal city of Famagusta. Its capture would establish by force the partition plan rejected by Greece at the Geneva peace talks.

Heavy fight ring has erupted around Hoi Nhon, in the central coastal area near Route a vital northsouth supply line, the Saigon, command said today. More than 70 Communist soldiers were killed in a clash there yesterday, it said. It put Government losses at 2 killed land 21 wounded.
Lord Mayor Arnulf Klett, whose 29-Year term in this city was West Germany's longest, died of a heart attack today. He was 69 years old.

Despite the protests of suburban homeowners here, construction of a $30-million downstate reception center for criminals will begin this fall near Mattawan State Hospital, Governor Wilson announced yesterday.

After a year of intensive effort, Senator Charles H. Percy has shelved his campaign for the 1976 Republican nomination for President. Mr. Percy, a liberal Republican from Illinois, said last night in Springfield, Ill., that President Ford had got off to an excellent start and that if he "continues to say and do the right things, he'll be nominated by acclamation" at the Republican National Convention in 1976.

Led by Arthur Ashe, the No. 1 seeded player, all the favored players easily scored opening-round singles victories today in the $50,000 Buckeye tennis championships, Ashe, however, was dissatisfied with his 6-1, 6-4 triumph over New Zealand's Jeff Simpson.

Willie Smith dashed 81 yards on a punt return and Alfred Jenkins teamed with George Mira on a record 95-yard scoring pass tonight to help Birmingham to a 39-0 World Football League victory over Hawaii.

An earthquake that swayed tall building jolted parts of Los Angeles County today but apparently caused no damage. The quake, which occurred at 7:46 A. M., was described by a spokesman for the Caltech Seismological Laboratory as "not very big, although I felt it here at my home in Pasadena.'

Kate O'Brien, the Irish novelist and playwright, died yesterday in a hospital near her home in Faversham, Kent. She was . 76 years old. Prizes for First Novel Miss O'Brien won two of the leading British literary prizes of the day-the Hawthornden and the John Tait Black-for her first novel, "Without My Cloak," published in 1931.

John J. Goepfert, who retired in 1971 as controller of the Schering Corporation, the pharmaceutical company, died Monday at St. Mary's Hospital in Orange, N. J. He was 68.years old and lived at 747 Berkley Avenue in Orange.
Greece withdrew her armed forces from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today, blaming her allies for not having prevented Turkey's new military advances in Cyprus.

Legal Aid Society lawyers returned to work in Brooklyn Criminal Court yesterday after a daylong boycott, They made their decision by a vote of 23 to 15 pending a solution of the issue that brought the walkout-a judge's sentencing of one lawyer to.a $50 fine or five days. in jail on a contempt citation.

Glenn McHugh, vice president of city mortgage operations for the Equitable Life Assurance Society in New York when he retired in 1960, died on Aug. 6 in Tipperary, Ireland, where he had been vacationing with his wife.

Fourteen new schools and some classrooms in more than 100 existing schools will not be ready when school begins on Sept. 9 because of job actions by electrical workers, the president of the Board of Education said yesterday.

The British Government suggested today that Turkey had planned to resume war on Cyprus even before the peace talks in Geneva collapsed early this morning.

The first faint strain in what President Ford had hoped would be "a good marriage" with Congress appeared today when he criticized extensive cuts that two Senate committees made yesterday in defense and foreign aid bills.

Iran has offered to lend money to the Grumman Corporation to enable it to continue production of the controversial F-14 fighter plane, Representative Otis G. Pike of Long Island disclosed yesterday. Iran has 80 F-14's on order.

With the breakdown of peace talks in Geneva, Turkey's accelerated military drive on Cyprus and Greece's with drawal of its forces from NATO, the full dimensions of the crisis in the Mediterranean have come abruptly into focus. The imminent dangers are of all-out war between Turkey and Greece and of collapse of NATO's southern flank, with ominous consequences for the entire eastern Mediterranean and the volatile Middle East.

MILWAUKEE-It is too early for a total assessment of Watergate's longrange impact on the Presidency. But there is a strong possibility that as Richard M. Nixon's successors put the pieces back together again they will find a few holes have been blasted through the walls that have isolated Presidents from political reality.

The American Bar Association, highly sensitive over the involvement of lawyers in the Watergate scandals, is getting some sharply contrasting views of what should be done to repair the profession and the Government.

Ted Turner was replaced as skipper of Mariner today as the. four United States yachts braced for the start tomorrow of the final trials to select the yacht that will defend the America's Cup next month.

An anonymous caller, apparently the one who earlier took responsibility for the bomb blast last week at Los Angeles International Airport, telephoned a local newspaper last night and said that the bomb had been revenge for the fatal shooting of two Mexican nationals by the police three years ago.

An error-filled boxing comedy in which no one got hurt but everyone was embarrassed ended yesterday when the State Athletic Commission formally called off next Monday's bout involving the world lightweight champion, Roberto Duran.
Henry C, Murphy Jr., a partner in the E. W. Howell Company, of Babylon, L. I., and New York, died Tuesday of a heart attack. Mr, Murphy, who lived in Garden City, L. I., was 53 years old.

Alma, the first tropical storm of the season, crossed the' Island of Trinidad today and, then crossed the Gulf of Paris and struck the peninsula on the northwest coast of Venezuela.

Chancellor Ernest L. Boyer of the State University announced in Albany that the university would send 10 students--six women and four men-to study for a semester at the State Institute of Foreign Languages in Moscow. The Atomic Energy Commission has recommended that restrictions on the enrichment of foreign uranium for use in domestic American nuclear power plants be relaxed starting in 1977. The proposals Would permit Canada and other foreign suppliers to be admitted gradually to the American uranium market, which has been closed to outsiders for the past 10 years.

The Navy's action last month in signing a $285.4-million contract for the first of its Trident missile submarines was taken despite protests from its outspoken director of procurement control, Gordon W. Rule, that the price was "phony" and that Pentagon directives were being flouted.

Mr. Alum is a native of Puerto Rico who began his training 15 years ago in Chicago before coming to New York to study.

A surprising discovery about the nature of the bacterium that causes syphilis has raised scientists' hopes that they can grow this organism for the first time in the laboratory and ultimately develop a vaccine against the potentially fatal general disease.

New York's new election campaign reform law has taken remarkably little time to prove itself remarkably ineffective. The few unspoiled coastal barrier islands still left off South Carolina are in danger of going from wild, windblown marshland and beach, teeming with marine and bird life, to elaborate resort colonies, complete mansions and golf courses. Dr. Edmundo de Lassalle of 635 Park Avenue, vice president of the International Fund for Monuments, an adjunct of the United Nations, died in London on Aug, 1. He was 57 years old.

Traffic on the Golden Gate Bridge has decreased in the last fiscal year for the first time since World War II. The bridge general manager, Dale W. Luehring, said that the 32,824,780 vehicles that crossed the span in the year ended June 30 was a 5.19 per cent decrease from the previous year, and was about the same as traffic in 1970.

White House officials said today that President Ford would probably announce next week the appointment of Richard L. Roudebush as head of the Veterans Administration.

Transamerican Trailer Transport, Inc., announced today, it would not sell its Puerto Rican.operations to the Government. The decision could end Government plans to establish a public merchant marine next month.

A panel of track officials in Kenya yesterday cleared Ben Jipcho of charges of professionalism that he had admitted to in a Sports Illustrated article three months ago. Jipcho, considered the world's most versatile distance runner, had said he accepted hundreds of dollars worth of gifts after running in Europe during the summer of 1973 when he was an amateur.

Bergen and Hudson County police today pursued a welter of tips, rumors and false alarms in their efforts to find the killer or killers of two local teen-age girls whose nude and sexually abused bodies were found in upstate Montvale yesterday, five days after their disappearance.

A group of program directors from city-financed drug programs held a stormy meeting with the head of the Addiction Services Agency yesterday, protesting the disclosure that some programs had been cut off from financing and that others faced the same action because of the poor quality of their services.
The Vietcong's Provision al Revolutionary Government, in its first public statement since President Ford took office, attacked him today for continuing aid to the Saigon Government.
Atlantic City Electric has received the first Energy Conservation Award of the Federal Energy Administration, it was announced here today.

Consolidated Edison announced that its bills would now show the amount of each dollar billed in the preceding 12 months that went for taxes and fuel. Joseph Block, the utility's executive vice president of division operations, said that for the year ended last June 30, 23 cents was collected for taxes and 33 cents for fuel.

A purported terrorist group callitself Aliens of America has asserted in a tape-recorded message that. it bombed the Los Angeles International Airport last week because of "immoral and anti-American immigration laws."
The House of Representatives gave final Congressional approval today, 377 to 21, to a compromise $11.2-billion housing bill, the first major housing measure to pass Congress since 1968.
Prodded by President Fore, three key Senators said today that agreement was near on al compromise on free emigration of Soviet Jews, an issue that has threatened enactment of a major trade bill.

Three inmates tried to escape from the Brooklyn, House of Detention for Men yesterday. One was shot, one surrendered and the third was recaptured after a short chase in downtown Brooklyn. The wounded man, Henry Brown, allegedly a leader of the Black Liberation Army, has a record of attempted escapes from custody.

Earnings of the New York Stock Exchange have gone the same direction of a majority of its member firms--down. Yesterday, the exchange reported that it earned only $193,000 in the second quarter this year, down from $2-million in the same period last year.

Negotiators in the National Football League labor dispute resumed contract talks today, the first time they had been to the bargaining table in 46 days without players on strike.

Governor Wilson yesterday announced the appointment of the nine members of a new state commission that will investigate complaints about the conduct and fitness of judges in the state. Only two of the commission's members are judges.
Juan Gisbert of Spain toppled top-ranked Jimmy Connors, 7-6, 6-2, in today's third round of the $130,000 Canadian open tennis tournament.

The House of Representatives narrowly upheld the concept of Federal subsidies for mass transit operations today and then voted to require localities to put up $2 for every Federal dollar received for such subsidies.

The International Harvester Company, a leading producer of farm machinery, motor trucks, industrial tractors and construction equipment, achieved the highest sales and earnings for the third fiscal quarter and nine months ended July 31.

The New York Stock Exchange is likely to reconsider its endorsement of a Government order that the brokerage industry "unfix" the commissions that Wall Street firms charge their customers for buy. ing and selling stock.

Industrial production remained virtually unchanged in July for the second consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Today's report was in line with the increasing number of forecasts, both inside and outside the Government, that the economy will show very little, if any, growth in the second half of the year.

The Senate voted-today to repeal tho year-round daylight time provision that Congress enacted in December in the energy crisis. By voice vote, the Senate chose to end year-round daylight time by accepting an amendment -to the energy research and development bill offered by Senator Robert Dole, Republican of Kansas.

American manufacturing, petroleum and mining companies plan to invest $21.6-billion in foreign countries this year, or 32 per cent more than they invested in 1973, the McGraw Hill Publications Company said yesterday. McGraw-Hill's annual survey of overseas operations also shows that investment will increase by 7 per cent to $23.2-billion in 1975 and by 10 per cent to $25.6-billion in 1976.
The State Civil Service Commission announced today that it had voted to abolish minimum height and weight requirements for candidates for municipal police jobs.

A 63-year-old man was found stabbed to death last night by policemen investigating a report of a robbery in progress in a store that sells Jewish religious items at 45 Essex Street on the Lower East Side.

Former, President Richard M Nixon was subpoenaed today to testify as a defense witness for John D. Ehrlichman, once Mr., Nixon's chief domestic affairs adviser, in the forthcoming trial of the Watergate cover-up case.

The Australian Government reported today that France had detonated a fifth nuclear bomb in her current Pacific test series, which has sent radioactive fallout over Australian territory.

AREA A Fishing in recent days has returned to normal after a northeaster on Saturday and Sunday drove the fish out to sea. Around Manasquan Ridge, blues averaging 10 pounds have been plentiful for fishermen using bunker backs, butterfish and smelts. Fluke up to 5 pounds have been moving into Manasquan Inlet and have responded to smelt, squid and spearing.

Christine Loock of Fort Worth edged a teammate, Cynthia Potter of Houston, for the Amateur Athletic Union women's national three-meter outdoor springboard diving championship today.

The wife of the President of South Korea, Mrs. Park Chung Hee, died tonight from an assassin's bullet evidently intended for her husband. The President was not hurt in the attempt by an assailant to shoot him this morning as he delivered a Liberation Day speech before an audience of 1,500 in the new National Theater here.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it had won orders for two turbine generators totaling $18.9-million. One, a 410,000-kilowatt generator, would go to the City Public Service Board of San Antonio, Tex., for $10.7-million and is scheduled for operation in December, 1976. The second, a 236,000-kilowatt unit for the Deerhaven Generating station at Gainesville, Fla., would cost about $8.2-million.

The defending champion, Carol Semple; Debbie Massey, Cynthia Hill and Peggy Conley reached the semifinals of the United States women's amateur golf championship today with victories in two rounds of match play.

A Federal judge presiding over the trial of two American Indian movement leaders ordered the White House today to retain certain tape recordings made in the Nixon Administration until it was determined whether the tapes had any bearing on the trial.
Negotiators for striking A. P. workers in the metropolitan area reached a tentative contract agreement with the supermarket chain last night after a crippling five-day strike.

New Jersey's measles epidemic, which reached record proportions in the state's northern and central counties last winter and this spring, appears to have "burned itself out," according to state and Federal medical authorities.

The American Bar Association endorsed today the proposed amendment guaranteeing equal rights for women and promised to work for ratification by enough additional states to write it into the Constitution.

Dr. Joaquin Balaguer was sworn in today for his third consecutive term as President of the Dominican Republic after a night shaken by 20 bomb explosions in the capital.

Fire that swept through a rambling frame nursing home today killed six persons and injured two others, one of them a nurse's aide, who had gone into the building to rouse the occupants.

When Vice President Ford tearfully invokes everyone's prayers for peace to Richard Nixon "who has brought peace to millions," Ford recklessly wields the spray can to embellish further the massive peace myth Nixon has so energetically created.

It's not the Ides of March the Los Angeles Dodgers fear. It's the night shades of August. Last year the Dodgers had a healthy lead in August but lost the Western Division pennant to the Cincinnati Reds.

The University of Illinois would not confirm or deny today a published report that the school's basketball team might be under a three-year probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Chicago Today said that Illinois "has been slapped with a stiff penalty by' the N.C.A.A. [reportedly three years of probation because of basketball recruiting violations] and already the penalty has been appealed."
The newspaper Sol said today that it would not publish for two weeks starting tomorrow an orders of the Ministry of Infomation.

The United States and its allies cannot condone Turkey's military conquest of the northern third of Cyprus in flagrant violation of United Nations cease-fire orders and NATO pledges reiterated by Ankara at Ottawa less than two months ago. To accept Turkey's aggression as a fait accompli would be to invite an endless period of bloodshed on the island and to risk collapse of the Western security system in the eastern Mediterranean.
The stock market, keeping consistently to its downward path, continued to decline yesterday, just as it has for the seven days since it became clear that Gerald Ford would replace Richard Nixon.

The New York Post and Typographical Union 6 have reached a tentative agreement on a contract running until March 30, 1984, that is similar to earlier pacts negotiated with The Daily News and The New York Times.

Arab oil money is being pumped out of a weak British economy for reinvestment in the United States, bankers said today. Large amounts of money with drawn in the last two days indicate Arab concern over the British economic outlook and a new-found confidence in the "Ford dollar," they said.
If the world's human population is increasingly starving for protein, that is not apparent in the marketing of the single most efficient protein sourcethe soybean.

Turkey's invasion forces completed the division of Cyprus into two areas yesterday and declared, a ceasefire. As the overwhelming military. offensive that had begun early Wednesday came to a halt, the northern third of the island was in Turkish hands.
The United Nations Security Council adopted a French resolution tonight recording its formal disapproval of unilateral military actions taken against Cyprus.
New Jersey announced today, that the financially troubled Gateway Insurance Company of Philadelphia has agreed to sign an order of insolvency in Pennsylvania.

The Centerport (L. I.), Yacht Club's Vengeance and Tortuga, representing Sagamore Y .C. of Oyster Bay, L. I., were winners of the International Offshore Rule Divisions I and II in the Junior Yacht Racing Association's Dorade trophy cruise series on Long Island Sound which ended today off Riverside Y C.

The Winged Foot Country Club course in Mamaroneck, N.Y., which had the world's best golf pros seeking counsel and consolation in June as the United States Open scores soared, is the creation of A. W. Tillinghast, who also designed the Ridgewood Country Club layout, the scene of the United States Amateur championship Aug. 26 through Sept. 1.

Gasoline prices in the New York area dropped slightly this week, but they continued to be among the highest in the country, according to the Automobile Club of New York.

Nearly all the eligible inmates at the Men's House of Detention - given the option of staying at the outmoded, facility or transferring to better facilities on Riker's' Island--chose yesterday to' stay, according to Benjamin J. Malcolm, the Commissioner of Correction.
Gasoline prices in the New York area dropped slightly this week, but they continued to be among the higest in the country, according to the Automobile Club of New York.
Women lawyers make more than women judges and both make about $10,000 a year less than male lawyers,. according to data prepared by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The White House announced today a major reorganization of its press operations, including the appointment of John W. Hushen as deputy press secretary.

A dramatic rise in export orders for grain and soybeans in recent weeks is expected to do more damage to the consumer's budget than the recent drought in the Midwest. Indian longshoremen unloading grain in Calcutta. In recent weeks there has been a dramatic rise in export orders for United States grains and soybeans.

NEWPORT, R. I.--When it was made known that Newport would play host this summer to "Monumenta," an open-air exhibition of largescale modern sculptures, no one knew quite what to expect. A work by David Smith in the garden of the Elms in Newport, R.I., part of an exhibition of large-scale modern sculpture that runs through Oct. 13. .

The diagnoses of five cases of malaria this summer in a three county area in northern Sacramento Valley have led California officials to move to prevent a smoldering "brush fire" from becoming a "forest fire."

Manner's stock, which like the Dow-Jones average had been plunging all summer, went up a point or two for an hour and three-quarters today at the America's Cup trial races. Mariner, left, and Intrepid appeared to collide as they maneuvered before race yesterday off Newport. Mariner lost to Intrepid, then to Courageous.

The ocean made Atlantic Beach what it is today-a sanctuary of private homes and cabana clubs and tanned healthy - looking residents. But now some of the "beach people" are insisting that their ocean has been turning foul, perhaps even unhealthy.

Carmen Toranzo sells pink silk sateen slips from the funky forties, Alex Dorin sells cast iron bits of old fire escapes, Danilo DeAngelis sells custom-made wooden toilet seats, and Roy Albanese sells so many sausage heroes on a Sunday afternoon that he sometimes has to make a run for more bread in his banana-colored Cadillac.
The American Film Institute has established a pilot program aimed at giving women greater opportunities in directing television and feature films.
The state announced today that the financially troubled Gateway Insurance Company of Philadelphia had agreed to sign an order of insolvency next week in Pennsylvania.

The Indiana Pacers of the American Basketball Association obtained a restraining order today barring the New York Knicks and the Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association from negotiating, with George McGinnis, the Pacers' star player. The suit was filed in Marion County Superior Court, and Judge Charles C. Daugherty set 'next Friday for' a hearing on an injunction.
Tim Moore of Ohio State won the men's oneneter springboard event tonight in the National Amateur Athletic Union diving champions at the Point Mallard Aquatic Center. He tallied 555.36 points.

Following are excerpts from an address by George Wald delivered in Tokyo on Aug. '2 at the 20th World Conference Against Atomic and Hydrogen Bombs. Dr. Wald, Higgins Professor of Biology at Harvard, won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1967.

Only 14 of the 261 inmates at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men who have been given the option of staying at the outmoded jail or transferring to newer facilities on Rikers Island have chosen to leave.
Saul Saphire, author of more than 100 novels serialized in Yiddish magazines and newspapers, died Thursday of cancer in Miami Beach. He was 78 years old and formerly lived here.

Dennis Ranks and Russell Means, the leaders of last year's Indian uprising at Wounded Knee, S. D., rested their defense late this afternoon after calling only two authors and three Sioux Indians as witnesses.
The Senate passed a $21.2billion appropriation bill today with nearly two-thirds of the money earmarked for the Veterans Administration.

EAST RUTHERFORD -Work on the 588-acre Sports Complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands is now moving at a pace that makes it possible to believe that the New York Giants will be able to play their 1976 football games in the new stadium.
Stacy Anne Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Lewis of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Gary Howard Strauss, son of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond S. Strauss of Freeport, L.I., and Danby., Vt.

Robert Frost liked secrets. "Don't trust me too far," he warned. Now, in the centennial year of his birth, it looks as if he has become America's foremost poet, its emblem poet. His picture is on a stamp: his residences are marked ("Seven colleges claimed me," he once said): his books and books about him are everywhere. But he still holds his secrets, and presumably we still cannot trust him too far.
In Christ Episcopal Church, Greenwich, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Melanie Lawrence Roome became the bride of Stephen Charles: Graham. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Seymour Flinn.

TRENTON--Members of the State Legislature will have a number of important issues to consider when their sessions are resumed next month, but perhaps the most pressing will be defining and funding a "thorough and efficient" education, as mandated by the State Supreme Court.

Margaret Macy, director of advertising, display and publicity for Bergdorf Goodman from 1933 to 1941 died Aug. 7 in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived here and in Sagaponack, L.I.
A 21-year-old West Side resident was arrested early yesterday morning after he allegedly Forced an 18-year-old girl into Central Park and raped her.
Dr. Peggy Anne McGuirk and Dr. Andrew John Franzone, attending physicians at Lenox Hill Hospital, will be married here Sept. 7 in St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church.

A Bronx woman's leg was severed and 27 other persons were hurt last night when a transit workers and their families from an outing upstate crashed off a rain-slickened highway exit ramp in the Westchester County town of Harrison, state police reported.

Like Secretariat in the Belmont Stakes last year, George Baker pulled far away from the rest of the pack early in the Governor's Cup hydroplane race today on the Navesink River and crossed the finish line before any of his competitors had even reached the final turn in the oval course.

Mrs. Helen Jones Miller of Rumson, N.J., and John W. Miller of New York and Long Beach Island, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jo Ann Miller, to Paul Fuller Timolat of Rumson, son of Mrs. Louis King Timolat and the late Mr. Timolat.

Forty-five mostly young middle-class Europeans who ended a one-month crash course about the United States yesterday found the country friendlier than they had expected, Washington a bit provincial, New York not as dangerous as advertised and prices similar to those in their own countries.

Donna Ann Fidelibus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Felix N. Fedelibus of Port Chester, N.Y., was married yesterday morning to Leo John Jarmusz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Jarmusz of Newtown, Conn. The Rev. Joseph P. Meehan performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the chapel of Manhattanville College in Purchase. N.Y.

MAPLEWOOD--From the outside, the white-frame house on Baldwin Road looks like any other comfortable family dwelling. However, its basement houses Atelier 3, a cooperative graphics workshop organized by three gifted local housewives.

Huey P. Newton, Black Panther party leader, was booked today for investigation of two counts of assault with a deadly weapon in connection with the pistol-whipping of his tailor and the shooting of a teenager, the police said.
The Army has made public a report saying it has not done a good job in the development and purchase of weapons.

Not even the fingers of one hand are necessary to count the harpists who have used jazz in their repertories. Casper Reardon was the pioneer of jazz harp in the nineteen-thirties: Robert Maxwell tried it after World War II, and in recent year Daphne Hellman has been mixing jazz and classical material.

Lay teachers at eight Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens have threatened to strike when school starts on Sept. 3 unless "significant progress" is made during negotiations over the renewal of a contract that expires on Aug. 31.

We can recall in clearly etched detail some fairly fancy spreads we've been privileged to enjoy around the world--fresh caviar in Iran; fresh foie gras in Aloace; bouillabaisse and bourride in restaurants around the Vieux Port in Marseilles.

Hundreds of thousands of new automobile owners, maybe more, have apparently joined the great interlock revolt and disconnected the safety system that was designed to guarantee that they were fully buckled into the cars before driving.

PRAIA, Cape Verde Islands. It is here, in this cluster of barren volcanic islands, that Portuguese colonialism reaches the heights of its sad absurdity. Before the Portuguese explorers, soon followed by settlers, arrived late in the 15th century, no one lived here.
Madison Avenue advertising. is helping to turn America into a nation of gulpers and snackers who often pay high prices for less nutritious foods, Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz said today.

SOUTHAMPTON--Since art became a prestigious item in the country a few years back, small-community art museums have been sprouting up almost as fast as golf courses. And one of the most remarkable of the small-community operations is the Parrish Museum.

The pro golf tour,'which breezed through here in June for the United States Open at Winged Foot, will make another stop in the metropolitan area this week. The occasion this time is the eighth Westchester Golf Classic from Thursday through Sunday at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison.

On the floor of a Saigon hospital ward a young seamstress named DangThi Hien lay handcuffed to an olive-drab stretcher. Her legs, covered with a blanket, were paralyzed--a result, she said of beatings and torture during police interrogation.

Patricia Grace Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Smith of Seattle, was married yesterday afternoon to Dennis J. Phillips, son of Mrs. George A. Phillips of Lowville, N.Y., and the late Mr. Phillips.

South Korcan investigators charged late last night that the President of Communist North Korea, Kim Il Sung, had ordered the attempted assassination of the President Park Chung Hee of South Korea last Thursday.
Scientists are looking at kelp, a seaweed, as a new energy source. The kelp is Macrocystis pyrifera, grown commercially off the California coast.

A citizens committee looking into the 11-month-old, $3million county jail in Kingston, N.Y., has reported that the institution is plagued by a disorderly administration, a low-paid staff and by repressive procedures that exceed the state's correctional facilities in restrictive practices.
Mary Ann Love, a vice consul at the United States Embassy in Oslo, Norway, was married there yesterday to Laurence L. Malinconico Jr., a graduate student in geology at the University of Oslo.

The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

Congress has emerged from the crucible of impeachment wearing a smile of selfassurance. It used to be the goat of government, the object of easy scorn and the subject of brittle humor. Its ratings in the public opinion polls were' below those of a beleaguered President.

President Ford has recently been reading and praising George E. Reedy's excellent little book. "The Twilight of the Presidency," and passing it out to members of his staff. This tells us something about the new sidpper, and his approach to his job.

Mr. Sulzberger intends to be disarming when he confesses, "At least I know I am a fool to write about China, whose language I do not speak, whose books or newspapers I cannot read, whose immense history I cannot pretend to know, and where I have no well-informed Chinese friends given to frank confidences."

SAIGON, South Vietnam--Arrests by the South Vietnamese Government are not always calculated, often having a random aspect, touching not only those who know they are taking risks but also those who apparently do not.
The top administrators of the Boy Scouts in the Chicago area have been censured and placed on one year's probation because their membership rolls were dishonest.

In a preliminary event in the developing plans to mark the country's bicentennial, the Long Island Historical Society is sponsoring a colorful exhibition of Revolutionary War documents, guns, maps, powder-horns and sworis this month at the Brooklyn Public Library's lain building at Grand Army Plaza.

September. And things are perking up a bit. On Monday night, President Ford told Congress inflation had now become America's public enemy No. 1. Yet the only policeman in sight of late has been Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve.

The Soviet Union agreed today to neatly double the price it pays Iran for natural gas, officials here said. When the price of oil rose last year, Iran demanded double the 30.7 cents per 1,000 cubic feet she was charging for natural gas, but Moscow rejected the demand.
The efforts by the Pittston Company of New York to build a $350-million oil refinery at Eastport, Me., have hit still another snag.

Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, said yesterday that "now is the time for the major leagues to have a black manager" and warned that "I could not function as commissioner" if a decision were long delayed.

Susan Elizabeth Sheehy, daughter of Mrs. Robert Dick Douglas Jr. of Greensboro, N. C., formerly of Manhasset, L. I., and the late Thomas Vincent Sheehy, was married yesterday afternoon to James Richard Cole, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Norman Cole of Camden, S. C.

Courageous and Intrepid, the two leading candidates for defense of the America's Cup, raced each other for four hours today on Rhode Island Sound and at the finish Courageous was ahead by two seconds.

In the securities markets, the first full week of the Ford Administration closed Friday afternoon and the word was hardly a vote of confidence. In contrast to the cooperative spirit reigning in Washington, it was gray days in the stock market, which dropped lower all week. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at its lowest point in four years. Interest rates continued to rise.

For six months last winter, until he was found out, Prof. Edward Brown earned salaries at a rate of more than $50,000 a year teaching sociology and social 'sciences full time at California State College in western Pennsylvania, at the State University of New York at New Paltz and at Bronx Community College-all at the same time.
NEWARK--This city, the largest in the state, is seeking a commercial television company to 'construct a cable system for its 382,000 residents. The deadline for applications is,Sept.1.
With the ailing George Sholty rooting from the paddock, Billy Herman, his 34-yearold assistant, drove Boyden Hanover to victory tonight in the Cane Pace final at Yonkers Raceway.

A three-year-old law designed to protect the thinning herds of wild horses in the West has apparently worked too well: The Government says the horse population has gone from 16,000 in 1970 to more than 42,000 now, and that it is time to protect them by thinning them out again.
American and Greek officials are now assuming that the United States will eventually be asked to vacate or reorganize at least some of the seven major military installations it maintains in Greece.

To the Editor: Having just returned from a trip through Southern New England, I want to say that I was aghast at the generally slovenly and in many cases filthy condition of the rest rooms in all of the half-dozen or so gas stations in which we stopped.

All summer long we have had the buzz and rattle, the shrilling and hum of beetles, grasshoppers, cicadas, mosquitoes and all their insect kinfolk. The sounds have become a part of the summer days, unheard unless we specially listen. But now comes the rasp and the monotonous scratch of cricket and katydid, and who dan ignore these sounds? They are a forecast of autumn frost and November silence.

Construction has begun on two new tennis centers in the city in response to still-growing demand. One is the $1.2-million Tennisport on the East River in Long Island City, Queens The 30 court indoor-outdoor center is scheduled to open in September on a five-acre site at Borden Avenue and Second Street, opposite the United Nations headquarters.

NEWARK--In a move designed to give it three times as much room for storage and public use, the New Jersey Reference Division of the Newark Public Library has moved its operations to the library's first floor.

Sigmund Sommer's 9-5 favorite, Infuriator, edged in front with a quarter of a mile to go and held on to win the fourth running of the $100,000 Hobson Stakes today by a neck over Ecole Etage at Liberty Bell.

The Turkish armed forces suffered 250 dead and 550 wounded in their operations on Cyprus, which began more than three weeks ago, according to Gen. Semih Sancar, the chief of the Turkish General Staff.
The manufacturer of a potentially dangerous full-size baby crib has agreed to buy back thousands of the beds because they fail to meet minimum Federal safety standards.

Sheila Miner Wolff, daughter of Mrs. Ronald Webb McCarthy of Rumson, N. J., and Jupiter, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to Edward John McCrossin 3d, who is with the New York law firm of Miller McCarthy. He is the son of Mrs. McCrossin Jr. of Red Bank, N. J., and the late Mr. McCrossin.
Christine Ann dl Sciplo, a teacher in St. Anthony's Grade School in Washington, and Michael Benson Soper, a senior at Georgetown University, were married at noon yesterday in Greenwich, Conn.

Johanna Davis was killed in a brutally freakish traffic accident on July 25, 1974, at the age of 36. She was the author of one novel, "Life Signs," published, by Atheneum, and very well received last year, a polished, comic, poignant piece of work done, after much struggle, perfectly in her own voice.

Angela Adele Parker, assistant professor of sociology at Green Mountain College in Poultney, Vt., was married yesterday morning in Poultney to Charles Michael Barsalow, proprietor, and manager of the Country Dollar Markets of Essex Junction, Vt., food and variety stores.
If Michelin awarded two stars to my favorite French restaurant in New York, it would list it as follows: XXXX ** La Grenouille (Masson), 3 E. 52d St., PL 2-1495. Closed Sundays, holidays and August.

Questions from readers about home repair problems should be addressed to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered in this column:
Congressmen identified in a Fort Worth newspaper article as practicing racial discrimination in hiring staff members angrily denied the allegation last night.

Kathryn Fisk Anthony, daughter of Lieut. Col. William H. Anthony, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Anthony of Heritage Village in Southbury, Conn., and Amjid Mohammed Sheikh, son of Dr. Mohammed Faquir of Soroti, Uganda, where he practices medicine, and the late Mrs. Faquir, were married yesterday afternoon at the Meeting House in Southbury.

A West German soccer star, Paul Breitner, has signed for the Spanish club, Real Madrid, at an estimated transfer fee of $1-million. A Rea Madrid spokesmann, announcing the transfer today, declined to specify the fee, though the million-dollar figure was thought likely here.
LAKEWOOD, N. J.-Two young Orthodox rabbis, discouraged by the difficulty of raising money for a religious school, have turned to land speculation as a way to help keep such institutions going.

Flood-devastated Bangladesh is desperately seeking help to pull through a developing calamity of epidemics and famine. "Without assistance from friendly countries," said Abdul Momen, Minister for Relief and Rehabilitation, "anything might happen."
GLADSTONE -- A man who can write, "It's so boring just being a hippopotamus," must have humor, imagination and whimsy. Above all, he must love children and animals.

George Cassidy, the race starter whom they call Flash because that's what he gets a field away from the post in, clambered into the station wagon and held the door open so a small boy could climb in after him. "This is Gregory," Cassidy said. "His mother works in the Stevens office and he helps me."
In recent years the London Festival Ballet under the artistic direction of Beryl Grey has made valiant efforts to extend what was its once somewhat moribund repertory.

Talks between National Airlines and the machinists union on a five-week-old strike that has shut down the airline have been recessed indefinitely, the chairman of the National Mediation Board said today.

PASSENGERS aboard United States airliners in the next few weeks may notice a transparent plastic badge, about two inches square, on the uniform of one of the flight attendants serving drinks and meals. The badge is called a thermal luminescent dosimeter, or T.L.D., and it contains five crystal beads that absorb radioactivity.

The late Catherine Drinker Bowen was a woman and a biographer of great style and force, and I recall a luncheon during the summer before last when she spoke feelingly about the relation between literary success and guilt.
After four rounds of the United States Open Championship at the Statler Hilton Hotel, 16 players held perfect scores.

Ending a long frequently bitter controversy among local governement agencies, Mayor Beame decided yesterday to permit construction of a 3,000 - foot rail spur through Forest park mass - transit line from Jamaica, Queens, to Kennedy International Airport.

TRENTON -- The state's Bicentennial Celebration Commission has selected three historically oriented sites for development into major tourist attractions during the nation's 200th birthday observance in 1976.

Al Oliver's eighthinning single drove home Richie Hebner with the winning run today and the Pittsburgh Pirates stung slumping Los Angeles, 4-3. It was the fifth consecutive loss for the Dodgers, leaders of the National League's West Division.

Private Papers Is not the title of Henry Kissinger's diary, an Agatha Christie thriller, or Queen Victoria's love letters to Prince Albert. It's the name of a stationery and writing accessories studio run by Jay and Jody Greif, who design just about everything a pen-pusher might want, from a complete desk set to a Lucite magnifying glass.

CALIFORNIA SPLIT, directed by Robert Altman from a screenplay by Joseph Walsh and starring George Segal and Elliott Gould, received a mixed reaction-from the critics. Vincent Canby reviewed it favorably.
MEDFORD--Many residents of this Burlington County township were upset over the fact that untreated sewage from neighboring Evesham Township was flowing down the southwest branch of Rancocas Creek.

With "The Billion Dollar Sure Thing," published just a little over a year ago, Paul Erdman established himself as the Adam Smith of the crime novel. Erdman, it will be remembered, was the financier who came to grief as president of a bank in Switzerland and served some time in a Swiss jail. It was there that he started his first novel, and it was a smash hit on publication.

Grace Mary Regan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Mahon Regan of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to John Joseph Conway 3d, son of State Supreme Court Justice Conway Jr. and Mrs. Conway of Rochester. The Rev. Leo J. Daly performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville.
Five mountain climbers, roped together for an ascent in the difficult Meije area of the French Alps were killed today when they fell off a sheer cliff, police officials said.

ONCE past the faces of manicured lawns, white picket fences and clipped hedges, there is an authentic flavor to Cape Cod. You can glimpse it in the thick stands of scrub pines along Route 6, the jewel-like miniature ponds and the harbors where seagulls swoop and soar.
A 17-year-old Rego Park, Queens, girl was found murdered and sexually molested in a schoolyard four miles from her home yesterday morning.

The South Street Seaport Museum was the setting yesterday for the First Annual Harmonica Brou-Ha-Ha, sponsored by the Hohner Harmonica Company to debunk the traditional image of the harmonica as the "country bumpkin" in the musical instrument family.

In dance things have been pretty cool for a hot August. At Lincoln Center, where American Ballet Theater and the National Ballet of Canada were playing across the plaza from one another, we saw some pretty remarkable dancing.
Representative Hugh L. Carey and Howard J. Samuels picked up additional endorsements yes. terday in their contest for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

To the Editor: Mr. Nixon's resignation has been followed by demands that he now be indicted and prosecuted for crimes that he allegedly committed during his tenure in office. Not long ago I learned in law school that under modern theories of criminal law, prosecution and punishment should be tailored not only to the crime committed but also to the person who committed the came.
Rebel gunners hit an American C-130 cargo plane over Angkor Wat today in the first such incident since the United states halted its bombing of Cambodia a year ago, reports from the field said.
Federal immigration officers say they apprehended 686,669 illegal aliens and seized $26-million in drugs and marijuana in the 10 states of the Pacific Southwest during the last fiscal year.

A new thrust southward on Cyprus by Turkish armor and artillery broke the ceasefire agreed on Friday night with Greek Cypriote forces. After seizing the northern third of the island, the Turkish Army appeared to be seeking to reach Turkish communities in the Greek Cypriote part of Cyprus.
The Staffordshire bull terrier has made it. This mediumsized, compact, short-coated dog is to be admitted for registry in the American Kennel Club stud book starting Oct. 1.
SAIGON, South Vietnam -- The South Vietnamese Government denies holding any political prisoners, and its view is upheld by the United States Ambassador to Saigon, Graham A. Martin.

MY next-door neighbor is delighted and astonished to find her tomato plants loaded with tomatoes. With the humility of a first-time gardener, she had assumed that growing vegetables requires years of apprenticeship.
Betty Walker, reminding her neighbors that former President Richard M. Nixon is human not divine, says she may keep a fourfoot color poster of Mr. Nixon on her front picture window forever.

The West German Interior Ministry is putting the finishing touches on a bill that would give journalists legal protection from editorial interference by publishers and impose "fairness" requirements for news coverage.

GREAT LAKES cruising has come back, at least for the summer. Recreating a once elegant travel tradition, the Stella Maris II, a Greek liner that formerly sailed the Aegean Sea, is offering the first passenger service on the Lakes in nearly a decade, at an all-inclusive price of $50 to $100 a day.

A new production or Eugene O'Neill's "Hughie," with Ben Gazzara returning to Broadway in the title role, has been scheduled for a local premiere on Oct. 15 at the Booth Theater, following successful runs in Chicago, where it played for three months, St. Louis and Los Angeles. The one-act, one-hour, two-character drama concludes there on Aug. 31 at the Huntington Hartford Theater.

AT this year's annual formal meeting of the Art Dealers Association of America and their guests, a New York art critic spoke briefly to the general effect that dealers have superceded artists, critics and even such proselytizing Institutions as the Museum of Modern Art as tastemakers to the 20th century.

I'M a radio buff In the age of tele vision, and that puts me behind the wheel, rather than behind the times. I drive a lot, both in this country and in Europe, on right- and left-handed roads, and I enjoy it, gasoline crisis or no, as long as the sound waves are clear.

SEOUL -- The Roman Catholic cathedral was jammed to overflowing. About 130 priests from all over Korea surrounded the high altar. Scores of gray-clad nuns filled the front rows. The congregation crammed into the aisles and spilled outside into the breathless hot summer evening.
Morty Domres passed for one touchdown and ran for another as the Baltimore Colts rolled up a 37-3 victory over the Cleveland Browns in a National Football League exhibition tonight.

Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut has approved the creation of 21 new administrative positions in the State Energy Agency to formulate an energy planning program. The fields they will study, generally, according to Lynn Allen Brooks, director of the Energy Agency, will be and use, the environment and transportation.
For the first time in the memory of most people in Washington, a President of the United States is actively seeking to restrain the prerogatives and the powers of his office.

Dave Stockton clipped two more strokes off par with a 69 today and expanded his lead to three strokes in the third round of the $200,000 Sammy Davis Jr.. Greater Hartford open golf tournament. His total of 199 is 14 shots under par.
Mrs. Carol Hofmann Thompson, the former United States Equestrian Team star, dominated the preliminary and junior jumper divisions today at the Monmouth County horse show.

It took the Yankees just about four hours to receive credit for a well-pitched 2-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox at Shea Stadium yesterday. Rain delays were the problem, and fewer than 1,000 persons were around from the original crowd of 14,587 when the umpires called the game at 6:30 P.M.
The California Supreme Court has ruled that justices of the peace who are not lawyers may no longer act in any case that might result in a jail sentence.
The Census Bureau says that the number of children in nursery schools more than doubled over the last 10 years while the nation's population of 3-to-5-year-olds declined.

TO anyone not part of the downtown labor force, a visit these days to the financial district can be quite shattering. The tip of Manhattan has long been the banking center of the world, and its charm, if that is the word, has traditionally been the spectacle of so many huge buildings packed into so small a space.

Doug Kotar was the last player to leave the Giant dressing room today after their 21-13 victory over the Jets.

Manchester united tans went on a rampage here today, smashing subway trains and fighting in the stands, as the new soccer season started. Police said at least 16 fans were arrested in central London and more than 200 were thrown out of Brisbane Road Stadium.
