Lowry Igleheart, a recent graduate of Smith College, and Aubrey Houston Keach Jr., who graduated from Vanderbilt University, plan to be married next July.

LAC DE SERT, MANIWAKI, Quebec--Shortly before midnight, the waning moon lifted over the dark hills and washed the long reach of Lac de Sert with a pale and holy light, and sitting in the dark on the porch of our cabin we watched meteors of the Perseids flash across the sky.
Rabbi and Mrs. David J. Seligson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Seligson, to Charles David Braver, a managing editor at MEDCOM, where the bride-to-be is an editorial assistant.

(The composer of so-called serious music is perhaps the most neglected of all artists today. To begin with, his potential audience is minuscule. Then, too, the chances of having his works performed are severely limited. Record sales are most unlikely and public recignition and acclaim are all but out of the question.

By Middle Eastern standards, the 12 weeks that have elapsed since the Israeli-Syrian troop-separation agreement was signed have been a tranquil time. There has been the odd skirmish on the Lebanese border, the occasional shelling of suspected Palestinian Guerrilla targets by Israeli gunboats. But in this fractious corner of the world, that sort of activity passes for peace.

Some 5,000 dinnertimes ago, Life magazine persuaded a junior inspector of the Guide Michelin to tour this country's leading restaurants and give a snap judgment. He was really impressed by one house, Le Pavillon, which he thought deserving of *** ("worth a voyage").
Marcia Dixcy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Dixcy of Verona, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to James Andrew Carr, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Carr of Greenwich, Conn.
Theodora Van Wagenen Ward, a writer and authority on the life and poetry of Emily Dickinson, died Friday in Keene, N. H., at the age of 83. She had lived in Cambridge, Mass., and Altead-Center, N. H.
Madison Avenue advertising is helping to turn America into a nation of gulpers and snackers who often pay high prices for less nutritious foods, Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz said today.

Allison Jill Boochever, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Paul Boochever of Westwood, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Brooks Hitchins Sawyer. He is the son of Howard G. Sawyer of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mrs. Sawyer.
ONE of the activities that engaged Pable Casals during the a last dozen during the last dozen years of his life was the performance of his oratorio El Pessebre in as many countries as possible.

Maria Luisa Biddle Duke, the daughter of Angler Biddle Duke, Commissioner of the New York City Department of Public Events, plans to be married next month to Frederic Ashton de Peyster 3d, a descendant of Mayor Abraham de Peyster of New York (16921694).
Curt Yarborough of Elk Grove, Calif., the 11-year-old brother of last year's champion, flashed under the checkered flag in a photo finish today to become the 37th AllAmerican Soap Box Derby champion.
Cynthia Hill defeated the defending champion, Carol Semple, 5 and 4, today to win the 74th United States Women's Amateur golf championship.

GENEVA--The opening of new Soviet-American nuclear missile talks, which Secretary of State Henry Kissinger announced last June in Moscow, has now been put off until after Labor Day. Mr. Kissinger's own busy schedule, delayed by impeachment politics, has not permitted him to devote much time to the subject.

Talk of world recessioneven depression -- was one of the products of the spate of oil-crisis rhetoric spawned around the turn of the year. The fear talk has faded somewhat, but the recession is all too tangible, at least for the industrialized sector of the world. And the extent of the swing into decline has been stunning.
It is hardly news that the explosive rates of world population growth threaten to overwhelm the development efforts of the "Third World" and lead to Malthusian famine, disease and despair.

The drought that is burning up grass on the Western ranges compounds the bad news for the livestock industry. Some ranchers are beingforced to reduce their herds by sending unfattened animals to the slaughter houses, and that will make for leaner financial returns in the months ahead. But the cattlemen were counting their losses even before the drought got this bad, and many of them are blaming not the weather but Washington for their difficulties.

EVERY society has its unspoken taboos. They linger in the twilight of public consciousness until something called bad taste brings them into the open. Bad taste triggers a kind of shock by the very fact that the unspeakable has been spoken, and the unpresentable presented.

Mr. and Mrs. Douglas D. Donald of New York and Dongan Hills, S. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Virginia Donald, to John E. Bloom, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Bloom of Chesterton, Ind. The wedding is planned for Nov. 23.

Where to get the money the Grumman Corporation needs to continue production of F-14 fighter planes has become an international mare's nest. The Senate has' voted to halt projected advance payments of $100 million by the Navy to bail out Grumman. The Iranian Government, with eighty F-14's on order, is eager to ease the problem by lending the company what it needs.
Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., breezed past Julie Heldman of Houston in straight sets today to capture the women's singles title in the Canadian open tennis tournament.

The Port Chester Water Works, whose 10,000 customers pay the state's highest and the nation's second-highest water rates, has touched off a howl of protest by asking the Public Service Commission for a 43 per cent rate increase.
New Jersey's small-claims courts, theoretically the "poor. man's court," where the consumer with a gripe can have his day, have been weighted in the balance and found wanting. John F. X. Irving

The Yankees got back to the .500 mark yesterday with one of their biggest offensive barrages of the season. They pounded four Chicago White Sox pitchers for 17 hits while coasting to a 9-4 victory before a crowd of 18,493 on a lovely, sunny day at Shea Stadium.
History began repeating itself this afternoon-but not for the Mets. By defeating New York, 6-5, the secondplace Cincinnati Reds moved to within 2 1/2 games of the slumping Los Angeles Dodgers,
Guillermo Vilas overpowered Manuel Orantes, 6-4, 6-2, 6-3, today to win the men's singles title in the $130,000 Canadian open tennis tournament.

Fuel dealers in the metropolitan area, looking beyond the current summer days, report that the supply of heating oil seems adequate for this winter, and they say it is unlikely that the price of the fuel will go up sharply from its present levels.
A 7-year-old borzoi, Ch. Loral's lossif Ivanevitch, the oldest dog in the ring, gave the five other finalists a lesson in showmanship today and took the top award at the Elmira Kennel Club's fixture.

Chris Evert, who failed to beat male horses in the Travers Stakes yesterday, will not run against them in the $250,000 Marlboro Cup Sept. 14. She will make her next start against fillies and mares in the $100,000-added Beldame Sept. 21, at Belmont Park, Joe Trovato, her trainer, said today.
The North American Soccer League's championship game, which will be televised nationally from the Orange Bowl on Sunday, will be between the Miami Toros and the Los Angeles Aztecs.
Russell B. Long won renomination to another term in the Senate in yesterday's Democratic primary, getting 75 per cent of the vote and carrying all of the state's 64 parishes.
The Federal Reserve kept its hands firmly on the credit wheel last week, although money market experts professed to be a bit uncertain as to what direction the central bank was taking.
A complete rendition of Arnold Schoenberg's infrequently performed cantata "Gurrelieder" will make up the final concert next Sunday afternoon of the Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood.

Over the protest table and not at sea, the yacht Mariner won one race and lost another today in the America's Cup final trials. No competition was scheduled but the New York Yacht Club Race Committee cleaned up the matter of three protests hanging from last Friday's races.

A return to wage and price controls as a way to fight inflation was favored by half the persons interviewed in a recent Gallup Poll survey. At the same time, 39 per cent opposed such controls, which were part of President Nixon's economic policy in 1971; 11 per cent had no opinion.

" Oh," sighed Patricia Stevens of Manhattan as she stared out the windows of a Culture Loop III bus. "The Bronx is so beautiful." The Bronx, hitherto known as the home of the cheer and the Bomber, is the latest area to be served by the Metropolitan Transit Authority's Culture Bus Loop tours.

Ann Freda Thomas and Daniel Lawrence Rabinowitz, who are students at the Yale Law School, were married yesterday at Congregation Sons of Israel in Cherry Hill, N.J. Rabbi Leon Katz performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Bernard Rothman.

The biggest real estate gamble currently being taken in Manhattan is the construction of a pair of apartment towers that will soar 45 stories from a block-square site on West 42d Street. Workers preparing foundation for the complex. Of more than 200 men on the project, a quarter are from minorities.
On the surface, it was a simple New York City political-racial dispute-an effort to appoint a black man to a middling municipal job that had been held by a Puerto Rican.
After 10 days of negotiations, a new price of 57 cents for every 1,000 cubic feet of natural gas sent from Iran to the Soviet Union has been agreed upon. The old price was 30.7 cents.

John P. Grasso figured he was ready. At 42, he had spent six years on the City Council. Now, redistricting had made this central Massachusetts manufacturing city of 30,000 the biggest population center and thus the key to the new Worcester-Middlesex state senatorial district.

Irving F. Singer, retired vice president of the Hugo Stinnes Company, a chemicals concern, died yesterday of cancer in Mount Vernon (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 336 Summit Avenue in Mount Vernon.

A tall intruder donned a green, ill-fitting doorman's uniform in the lobby of a West Side luxury apartment building just after noon yesterday arid, with polite greetings and a menacing gun, robbed tenants in bunches as they strolled in.

Governor Wilson said last night that because President Ford "is a resident of either Grand Rapids, Mich., or Washington, D.C.," the Presi. dent would be neither invited nor welcomed to come to New York to campaign for Republican candidates this year.

Manny Reiner, executive vice president for international sales Paramount Television, died Saturday of a cerebral hemorrhage at his summer home in Westhampton Beach, L. I. He was 59 years old and lived at 40 Central Park South.

The collapse of Bankhaus I.D. Herstatt or West Germany seven weeks ago and the troubles experienced by the Franklin National Bank of New York and a number of leading European institutions have brought about a drastic contraction of international banking activity.

Edward W. Kilpatrick, former Acting Commissioner of Education in New Jersey, died yesterday of congestive heart and kidney failure in Beth Israel Hospital in Newark. He was 68 years old and lived in New Providence, N. J. Edward W. Kilpatrick

The Brazilian Bar Association has called for the legalization of divorce as a basic human right in this large Roman Catholic country. WASHINGTON- We have a new President and it is a time for new beginnings. It is an opportunity to grapple with the great problems that confront our nation and the world. In his inaugural speech, President Ford identified inflation as the nation's most urgent problem.

Howard Hunt Jr. said today that, as far as he knew, the seven mysterious cartons stored in his White House office after the Watergate break-in in June, 1972, contained hundreds of copies of a book-length criticism of television news reporting but no information concerning former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York.

August rains apparently were not enough to significantly improve the gloomy 1974 corn production outlook caused by the drought in June and July, a special Agriculture Department report said late today. Delegates from the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and a few members of the Policemen's Wives Association took part in the demonstration, led by the P.B.A. president, Ken McFeeley.
Tom Seaver, the New York Mets' strongboy, turned in one of those superb performances against the Astros tonight that has enabled him to become the major league's highest salaried pitcher.

The Hewlett-Packard Company, maker of electronic instruments and data processing equipment, yesterday reported a 118 per cent increase in earnings for the third quarter ended July 31 on a sales gain of 42 per cent. Nine-month earnings rose 72 per cent and sales 41 per cent.

The rates of Treasury bills rose today as the Government borrowed $2.7-billion on 91-day and 2-billion on 180-day bills.

A Florida couple filed a $1.5-million damage suit in United States District Court here yesterday, alleging that a New York doctor last year had "maliciously destroyed" a test-tube culture from which they had hoped to have a baby.

Rushing down one of the East's great scenic whitewater routes, Governor Byrne will lead a fleet of 25 canoes and power boats on a 10-mile Delaware River excursion today to inspect the site of the controversial Tocks Island Dam and the region that would be flooded if it is built.
The House of Representatives voted today, 381 to 16, to return the nation to standard time from the end of this October until the end of next February.

More than 350 women, mahy of them black and Puerto Rican mothers, learned hoW to avoid becoming victims of sexual attack, when the New York City Police Department and Rape Coalition Educational Outreach Van visited the South Bronx.

Claude Osteen, obtained by St. Louis earlier this month from Houston as 'pennant insurance, made his first start last night for the East ern Division-leading Cardi nals and promptly ran into a barrage of Atlanta base hits led by an old nemesis.

Three years after the presentation of "The Selling of the Pentagon," its controversial documentary on the public relations efforts of the armed forces, CBS-TV will televise on Sept. 6 a report on the United States military during

American and Philippine military helicopters began a joint airlift of food, candles, medicine and clothing to more than half a million refugees from floods in central Luzon provinces north of Manila today.

Marion Williams is perhaps the most loved and respected of the present-day gospel singers, yet her appearances here are distressingly rare. Thus it was a pleasure to welcome her to the generally comfortable ambiance of an outdoor concert yesterday noon in Bryant Park, even if the sound system didn't always do her justice.

Responding to rising demand by food and soft drink makers for an inexpensive substitute for sugar, the Amstar Corporation said yesterday it was spending more than $20-million to expand its capacity to make high-fructose corn syrup.
Carla Linke was the star of the second day of the European swimming championship today as the East German women went on another world-record shattering spree.
CENTER OF ATTENTION Lincoln Center observes the closing of the summer with an explosion of creative activity, starting today.
The International Paper Company considers itself to be in the running for the General Crude Oil Company even though the principal stockholder of the oil exploration and producing company appears

John C. Sawhill, head of the Federal Energy Administration, said yesterday that there would likely be curtailment of natural gas supplies in the Northeast next winter, leading to plant closings and loss of jobs.

The United States dollar made fresh gains on world money markets today, climbing to its highest level in five months here and in Frankfurt. Gold prices moved irregularly, but closed the day with gains.

With an eye on cost-cutting and better performance, the Police Department has begun replacing its standard-size radio patrol cars with a smaller, intermediate model that drivers say handles better and has more zip.

Steel production fell to 2.68million net tons in the week ended Aug. 17, a decline of 2.1 per cent from the previous week, The American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The production index, with 100 equaling the 1967 weekly average, dropped to 109.7 from the previous week's 112.0.

The Congressional Office of Placement and Office Management acknowledged today that some Congressional offices had requested that it send white ap plicants only for interviews to fill staff job vacancies.

A historic event in the world of tennis passed almost unnoticed recently: a professional player was defaulted during a singles match for stalling and foul language. The default occurred during a major tournament, the $100,000 United States clay-court championships at Indianspolis. The player involved, as you might have guessed, was Ilie Nastase of Rumania.

Colin J. H. Browning, who was manager in Japan for the Chartered Bank of London before retiring in this country, died yesterday in Morristown (N. J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived on Hainsburg-River Road in Knowl. ton Township, N. J.

As President and Mrs. Ford stepped out of Air Force One here this morning, a voice boomed importantly over an airport microphone: "Ladies and gentlemen, the President of the United States and Mrs. Nixon."

Turkish officials said the killing today of Rodger P. Davies, the United States Ambassador in Cyprus, was an example of the kind of violence that the Turkish Cypriote minority on the island had faced for years from Greek Cypriotes.

"About 5 A.M. Dec. 26 we were handcuffed together and transferred to a ship, No. 504, about 450 or more prisoners. We were put into the hold of the ship, shackled to bars. There were four policemen guarding us.
SAIGON, South Vietnam After two decades of fratricidal warfare the Government of South Vietnam has been left with a legacy of corrosive suspicions directed in large measure against its own citizens.
By the time President and Mrs. Ford returned from their trip to Chicago today, their family belongings were all moved into the White House and the family cat was asleep in the Presiden. tial bed.

The State Power Authority has added Arthur Kill, an industrial section of Staten Island, to the list of possible sites for a projected generating plant whose output would power the city's subways and commuter trains after 1980.

A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted two partners in a now-defunct stock brokerage firm on charges that they conspired five years ago to violate Federal securities laws. The 16-count indictment handed up in United States District Court, Manhattan, named Charles D. Erb,
Almost every leader of the South Korean Government and ruling party submitted his resignation today to take responsibility for the attempted assassination of President Park Chung Hee last Thursday.

The Metropolitan Opera's innovative Mini-Met is being revived this coming season, Schuyler G. Chapin, general manager, confirmed yesterday. The Mini-Met performances, begun in February and March, 1973, were suspended last season for lack of funds.
The Hoffman Electronics Corporation has announced that it will discontinue its metal products division as a result of the loss of an Air Force contract on the BL U-63B aircraft.

Ruth Bates Harris, a black woman who was dismissed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration after she wrote a report accusing NASA of having the worst record in the Government in hiring minorities and women, returned to the agency yesterday in a new and better-paying job.

Dr. John A. Morsell, assistant executive director since 1964 of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died yesterday in Kings County Hospital after suffering a massive arterial hemorrhage at his home, 95 Fenimore Street, Brooklyn. He was 62 years old.
Bache Co., the New York City brokerage house, announced yesterday that it had purchased two branch offices of Steiner Rouse Co., Inc. in Mobile and Birmingham, Ala. for an undisclosed amount.

Prof. Howard Dykema Roelofs, head of the department of philosophy at the University of Cincinnati for many years, died Aug. 12 at his home, Arden Farm in East Aurora, N.Y., where he had lived since his retirement in 1959. He was 81 years old.

A Federal district court in Richmond yesterday granted : Chessie Systems, Inc., a railroad holding company, a temporary injunction it had sought restraining the Interstate Commerce Commission from requiring all railroads to earmark funds derived from a 10 per cent rate increase permitted on June 20 for deferred maintenance and postponed capital improvements.
Morris Sprayregen, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla., where he had lived since last year. He was 84 years old.

George McGinnis a Knick? The wheels are in motion to bring one of the American Basketball Association's more valuable properties to New York. Apparently, only the law courts stand in the way of it happening before the start pf the National Basketball Association season in October.

President Ford has narrowed his Vice-Presidential list to "five or six" Republicans with varied experience in political office, the White House said today. After talking with all of the possible nominees to get their ideas on the Vice-Presidency, Mr. Ford will announce his choice tomorrow, a spokesman said.
Inflation and its effects on consumers and producers continued to have diverse results on retail merchandising chains, according to figures announced yesterday. by four major Companies.

Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn filed a $5-million suit yesterday, charging that he had been libeled by Jack Newfield in a series of articles originally published in The Village Voice and later as a book, "Cruel and Unusual Punishment."
SAIGON, South Vietnam After two decades of fratricidal warfaree the Government of South Vietnam has been left with a legacy of corrosive suspicions directed in large measure against its own citizens.
After three strike-weakcned preseason games in which National Football Leagues teams lost hundreds of thousands of dollars, the league decided yesterday to stop giving refunds on exhibition games.

Love may or may not make the world go 'round but it certainly makes Jon Lucien's concerts go on and on. Listening to Mr. Lucien's lyrics (he is a singer from St. Thomas, West Indies, and made his Avery Fisher Hall debut Sunday) it is easy to see that he is of the love generation.
The $50,000 MediQuik tennis open began today and if Paul Gerken is lucky, Mrs. Ida Mae Gocke will cook him a terriyaki dinner.

The major cereal manufacturers, late converts to the natural cereal craze, have made up for their early reluctance with a purer-thanthou competition that has resulted in big-name natural breakfasts stripped of all things artificial, the nutritious as well as the extraneous.
The Greek Government today made changes in the command struc ture of the armed forces in a major step to break the power of the military, which ruled for seven years.
President Ford said today that he favored "leniency" for the nation's estimated 50,000 military draft evaders and deserters "to bind up the nation's wounds."

Under tile new housing bill, seven existing grant programs for such purposes as Model Cities, urban renewal, and neighborhood facilities would be combined into a new $8.4-billion program of community development block grants for the next three years. In addition, the Department of Housing and Urban Development will seek additional funding to spread the block grant program to six years.
Applauding, whistling and cheering, members of the Veterans of Foreign Wars were on their feet today before President Ford could finish his sentence naming their former
The University of Illinois basketball team was placed on probation today for two years by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for recruiting violations.
Laura Dreyfus Barney, a member of the International Council of Women, died yesterday at her home here. She was 94 years old.

Jorge Velasquez's riding generalship and Fairway Flyer's liking for the turf made for a winning formula in the $58,450 Diana Handicap today. The 5-year-old mare owned by William Floyd moved up from seventh place in the field of nine to take the 1-1/8mile grass race by two lenths.

With an eye on cost-cutting and better performance, the Police Department has begun replacing its standard-size radio patrol cars with a smaller, intermediate model that drivers say handles better and has more zip.
A city officer was shot to death last night in a neighborhood of South Jamaica, Queens, that has been marked by periodic flare-ups and animosity between the police and residents.

Nassau County Judge Alexander Vitale today sentenced Armand Pollastrino, 54 years old, of 5 South 16th Avenue, Mount Vernon, to six months in the Nassau County jail in East Meadow for criminal contempt of a 1970 grand jury investigating infiltration by organized crime into legitimate business operations.

The state has exempted pickup truck owners and operators of leaf composting facilities from payment of state solid-waste fees. David J. Bardin, Commissioner of Environmental Protection, said the $45 annual pickup truck fee had been eliminated from the solid-waste management rules because the state did not intend to require registration for people handling household and agricultural wastes.

In his wise and compassionate statement on the muchdebated subject of amnesty for Vietnam draft evaders, President Ford has demonstrated his fidelity to the principle that the rule of law applies to all Americans but that its application necessitates no conflict between the noble aims of mercy and justice.

The effort of scientists to demonstrate the existence of extrasensory perception (E.S.P.) and other so-called psychic phenomena suffered what many observers consider a serious setback recently when it was discovered that the director of one of the best-known parapsychology research centers had been falsifying his experimental data.
More than 18,000 A. employes returned to work yesterday after a six-day strike that won them wage increases of about 35 per cent over three years and improved fringe benefits.
A new corporation has been formed in Kuwait to take charge of Kuwait's interests in oil and gas operations in and outside the country, according to the Middle East Economic Survey.
Vlastimil Hort, the Czech grandmaster, managed to open a crack between himself and the rest of the field competing in the United States Open championship at the Statler-Hilton.

Larry Csonka and Jim Kiick, the stellar running backs who are headed for the World Football League next year, started their final season with the Miami Dolphins tonight by leading the way to a 21-9 exhibition victory over the Minnesota Vikings.

The likelihood of any decisive international action soon to defuse what many experts have called the global "population bomb" seemed dim today as the United Nations World Population conference opened here.

The deserted little two-story white frame fire boat house stands alone at the foot of CadmanPlaza West in Brooklyn Heights and in the shadow of the vaulting Brooklyn Bridge. Its trim tower is framed by those of the World Trade Center, which soar into the sky directly across the East River.

Albert L. Lewis, managing editor of Aerofile Books since 1972 and aviation editor for Conde Nast Publications from 1960 to 1972, died Friday of a heart ailment at his home in Bellmore, L. I. His age was 59.

Secretary, of State Kissinger, seeking -to persuade Greece to resume peace talks with Turkey in the Cyprus crisis, pledged today that the United States would use its influence "in any negotiation to take into full account Greek honor and national dignity."

Alexander Janta, a Polish writer, poet and translator and former director of the Paderewski Foundation, died yesterday in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 88-28 43d Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens, and in Hampton Bays, L.I.
Investors concern over the inflationary trend and the unsettled situation in Cyprus sent prices down sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market.

The first world amateur boxing championship had its first drama last night when a Swiss competitor had to be carried out on a stretcher after being knocked out by a Bulgarian middleweight, Alexander Yanakiev. It took Cuban Red Cross officials several minutes to revive Guido Corpateaux after he was knocked flat on his back by a left to the chin.
An armed forces group is ruling Ethiopia in all but name now, and the big question here is whether it will push aside Emperor Haile Selassie completely.
Three hun-k dred Creeks and Greek Cypriotes demonstrated today in central Paris to protest against the crisis.

Federal District Judge John J Sirica ruled today that the trial of the defendants in the Watergate cover-up case would begin as scheduled on Sept. 9, notwithstanding requests by both the prosecution and fout of the defendants for a delay

The first draft Of the revised city-state plan for meeting Federal air-quality standards was criticized yesterday by the Federal Government as inadequate "in its present form."

City attorneys have ruled that Dallas policemen may no longer arrest Mexican aliens for being in the country illegally. Under the ruling, they may arrest the aliens only for breaking state or municipal laws. It is estimated that there are more than 30,000 illegal Mexican aliens in Dallas.

Thanks to a totally ineffective performance by Sam McDowell as the starting pitcher, the Yankees never had a chance in the opener of a three-game series against the Minnesota Twins last night at Shea Stadium.

The New York Athletic Club won the chance to challenge the United States team quadruple sculls crew for the right to represent the United States in the world championships at Lucerne, September 4 to 8. No competition appeared yesterday for a qualifying race against the Winged Foot boat on the Orchard Beach lagoon.

The financial and operating practices of the State University Hospital ,of the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn have been criticized in an audit released yesterday by the office of State Controller Arthur Levitt.

A group of New York and New Jersey residents filed suit to day in Federal Court here to block construction of a giant natural-gas storage tank that they contend is "intended to t store the destructive equivalent of 37 atomic bombs."
The Common Council took four ballots tonight to elect Richard Maas, a Democrat, Mayor of White Plains replacing Acting Mayor Michael Keating.

The quietly simmering campaign for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination heated up a bit more yesterday as the two candidates held news conferencess to repeat charges and defenses they had made over the weekend.

The city said yesterday it would solicit bids for the private development of the largest tract of its undeveloped land other than on Staten Islandmore than 400 acres on the Brooklyn-Queens border-for a housing, recreational and industrial complex.

Most of the debate about whether it is fitting to jail an ex-President is so high-flown that one feels a bit timid about injecting some realism into it. It is with considerable diffidence, therefore, that I suggest that the whole debate is silly.

Counterfeiting in New Jersey decreased sharply in the last year, according to the Secret Service. In the year ended June 30, 36 persons were arrested and $445,000 in counterfeit money was confiscated in the state, according to Paul Scanlon, agent in charge of the Secret Service in the state.

The Department of Community Affairs announced today that a grant of $83,725 had been awarded to the Black People's Unity Movement in Camden to establish a tenant counseling and education program in the four lowincome apartment developments it manages.

Many nervous traders holding large paper profits were stampeded into selling their grain and soybean contracts yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The selling was provoked in the last hour by a sharp break in soybean prices, which carried the far deliveries down by the 20 cent-a-bushel daily limit.

A sharply divided House Ways and Means Committee tentatively approved a key financing feature of a compromise health insurance bill today after narrowly rejecting two rival ideas.

Nelson A. Rockefeller, 66-year-old former Governor of New York, was nominated as Vice President by President Ford, who, in a simple White House ceremony, called him "a good partner." Aides said he had been chosen as the best-qualified Republican to "step into the Presidency should that need arise."

The trustees of the Penn Central Railroad in a .100-page brief filed with a special three-judge court in Washington yesterday supported a Federal District Court finding that the Penn Central should not be reorganized under the Rail Reorgani.

The Wimbledon champion, Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., and Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union, the first- and second-seeded players, respectively, survived first-round matches today in the $50,000 Medi-Quik open tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
Lee A. Jacocca, president of the Ford Motor Company said today that the $500 price increase generally expected on 1975 model cars "is not the end" of the rises probable for the new autos.

Two young gunmen forced their way into a Woman's East Harlem apartment at about 10 A.M. yesterday, seized $400 and then forced her to withdraw $8,000 from a nearby bank while three members of her family were held hostage, the police reported.
The Federal Energy Administration reported today its auditing of oil-company operations had resulted in 10 oil companies repaying a total of some $103.7million in alleged overcharges.

The Gulf Oil Corporation plans to resume in October its test drilling in the fourth block of South Korea's continental shelf, west of Cheju island, the Commerce and Industry Ministry reported today.
State Senator Thomas Stroock breezed to an easy primary election victory over two opponents today to win the Republican nomination for Wyoming's only seat in the House of Representatives.
About a year and a half ago, when Newmont Mining offered to merge with Foote Mineral on the basis of $9.50 of debentures for each Foote share, management rejected the offer as inequitable.
Price increases announced yesterday covered sugar, solvents and iron ore and amounted to 14 per cent in some bases.
The Senate failed by three votes today to end debate on legislation that would create a new agency to represent consumer interests within the Federal Government.
Speculators sold dollars today, seeking to lock in a quick profit, but while the sales slowed the steady climb of the American currency, they did not halt it.

Of all New York City's mountainous problems, the most pressing remains jobs. The Securities and Exchange Commission today scheduled public hearings for Sept. 24 on the request of the New York Stock Exchange for a further increase in nonmember fixed commission rates on orders valued between $2,000, and $300,000.

Lack of adequate financing and a reduction in projected electricity consumption today forced the Duke Power Company to impose delays of up to two years on proposed nuclear generating facilities. "Duke has thoroughly investigated all available means of financing and is convinced that it is impossible to raise the huge sums needed to maintain the former construction schedule," said Carl Horn Jr., president of the utility.
President Ford crossed party lines today as he personally put up in the Cabinet. Room a portrait of one of his favorite Presidents, Harry S. Truman.

Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain is on an island, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany is on a lake, President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France Is on the Riviera. In short, Europe's leaders are on vacation. Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany vacations at northern lake. President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France at an estate near Nice.

In this age of vanishing medical house calls, a Bronx man was arrested yesterday on charges of being all too willing to make them. District Attorney Mario Merola charged him with impersonating a physician.
Rick Hobard, the producer of "Find Your Way Home," sought an injunction in State Supreme Court yesterday to prevent his star, the Tony Award-winner, Michael Moriarty, from leaving the Broadway play.

IRT passengers being rescued from tunnel fire below East River. Man at right was given oxygen and hospitalized.
The Western Fishboat Owners Association and four tuna-boat owners filed suit in Federal court today accusing five major tuna-fish canners of violating antitrust laws.

The United Mine Workers of America came out today against construction of a mammoth hydroelectric project ,by the American Electric Power system on the New River in western Virginia and North Carolina.

Governor Byrne led a. flotilla of 50 canoes, kayaks and power boats filled with newsmen, politicians, conservationists and Army engineers early today on a water-splashing 10-mile inspection tour of the proposed Tocks Island dam site.

Lee Richardson, who resigned as head of the Federal Energy Administration's Office of Consumer Affairs on Aug. 8; squared off today against his old boss over charges by the former consumer chief that he had been allowed no voice in police decisions.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished lower yesterday for the eighth consecutive session. Prices on the over-the-counter market were mixed.

The Rev. Joseph O'Rourke baptizing 3-month-old Nathaniel Ryan Morreale on the steps of Immaculate Conception Church in Marlborough, Mass. Carol Morreale held her son.

Arnold Miller, president of the United Mine Workers of America, said yesterday that the current week-long nationwide shutdown of bituminous coal mines by his union had been called as a memorial to men killed and injured in the mines, not to support striking workers at two mines in Harlan, Ky.
Andreas Papandreou, one of the leading figures of the Greek left, does not intend to organize large public demonstrations here, because he fears they could bring back military rule.

The Atomic Energy Commission released today a study of nuclear power plant safety indicating that the chance of mass destruction from an atomic reactor accident was as unlikely as that of a meteor striking an urban area--once in a million years.

Latin America's largest, fastest-growing industrial capital has been stricken by a serious meningitis epidemic. Officials are reluctant to give the death toll, but knowledgeable epidemiologists estimate that 800 to 900 people have died this year in greater Sao Paulo, an area with seven million inhabitants. Nelson A. Rockefeller, 66-year-old former Governor of New York, was nominated as Vice President by President Ford, who, in a simple White House ceremony, called him "a good partner." Aides said he had been chosen as the best-qualified Republican to "step into the Presidency should that need arise." The move also broadens Mr. Ford's political base for the 1976 election the selection of a moderate Eastrner.

The White House is reviewing former President Richard M. Nixon's nomination of Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut for a vacancy on the United States Court of Appeals, but a spokesman said a recall of the nomination was unlikely..

The nomination of Nelson A. Rockefeller as Vice President assures the nation that, in an emergency, there will be available in that post a man of Presidential quality. After careful deliberation President Ford has chosen his party's most experienced state executive, a man well-versed in economic and foreign affairs and in the domestic side of the Federal Government. It is a responsible and encouraging nomination.

A Jersey City detective has been indicted here on charge of attempting to shake down an Englewood physician for $20, 000.

He was 74 years old and lived at 144 East 84th Street.

The Senate passed and returned to the House today a compromise bill that would give veterans attending school under the G.I. bill a 23 per cent increase in monthly benefits.

President Ford's hopes of having Congress pass this year a national health insurance bill, his major domestic proposal, appeared dashed today by what seemed to be a hopeless deadlock in the House Ways and Means Committee.

Although disappointingly inadequate in its funding provisions, the six-year mass-transit bill passed overwhelmingly by the House represents a significant advance in Federal support for public transportation. If adopted by the Senate and signed by President Ford-both reasonable prospects-this pioneering legislation would establish the concept of sustained subsidies for mass-transportation systems throughout the country, in both urban and rural areas.
Personal income and new or ders for durable goods both ders for durable goods rose strongly in July, the Commerce Department reported today.

Don Growley is a long-distance runner-but he isn't lonely. The 32-year-old Madison High School mathematics teacher has a lot of company when he works out on the grounds and track of the high school. As underr and director of the Bottle Hill Athletic Club, Growley has more than 40 club members-male and female, ranging in age from 7 to over 40-to run with.
The steep rise in consumer prices moderated, at least temporarily, in July, the Labor Department reported today.

Three motions to suppress evidence were filed in United States District Court yesterday on behalf of C. Arnholt Smith and Philip A. Toft, both former executives of the financially troubled Westgate-California Corporation.
In the view of some consumer and nutrition experts, the snaring cost of sugar in recent months is the best inflation news yet. Since Jan. 10, the price of a five-pound bag has doubled to $1.80.
The Army reported yesterday that Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, Army Chief of Staff, was being treated in Walter Reed Army Medical Center for a blood clot and that he is in serious condition.

Alex Webster, former New York Giants coach, was reported in good condition today at St. Elizabeth's Hospital. He was admitted yesterday for treatment of dizzy spells. Webster, 44 years old, spent the night in the intensive care unit but was to be transferred to a private room, doctors said.

The United Aircraft Corporation yesterday was awarded $98.8-million in Navy contracts. The contracts cover production of J-52 and PF-30 engines. The J-52 is used by the Navy on Grumman A6 and McDonnell Douglas A4 aircraft and the PF-30 on F-14 aircraft.

Harry C. Yoxall, director of the old Alfred Coming Clark Neighborhood House at 283 Rivington Street, on the Lower East Side, died Tuesday in the Coral Gables Convalescent Home, Miami. He was 99 years old.

In an effort to "bring the hospital emergency room closer to the community," the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday graduated its first class of paramedics at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center.
Highly placed Turkish sources denied today that any moves toward annexation of territory were being made in Cyprus that would preclude a negotiated settlement with Greece on the future of the island.

You have to look hard these days, on Broadway or off it, to find a genuinely adult drama about man and God, or a musical with real music and real characters. In a welcome splash of color Off Off Broadway, the Malachy Company has appealingly revived Graham Greene's "The Potting Shed," while a new unit of youngsters called the Octagon Theater Club is reprising "110 in the Shade" with freshness and verve.

The Federal Reserve Board proposed today a new regulation that would permit a higher interest rate on "discount window" borrowings by banks that need "exceptionally large assistance over a prolonged period of time."
The House of Representatives tonight overwhelmingly approved a bill that would authorize the Federal Government to study all foreign investments in the United States. The vote was 324 to 29.
Spain announced today that she would hold a referendum in her northwest African colony of Spanish Sahara next year to allow the people there to determine their political future.

Mary Weeks Patterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Briant Weeks Patterson of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon in Winchester, England, to the Rev. Dr. Dougald Lachlan Maclean, rector of - St. George's Episcopal Church in Flushing, Queens.

Mayor Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City said the city planned a $150-million, 18-acre development along the Hudson River at Exchange Place. The Mayor announced the plan after the City Council named Milton L. Ehrlich, Inc. of New York City as the project's developer. The Mayor said the plans call for 2,000 upper- and middle-income apartments, a hotel with convention rooms, offices, a marina, a promenade and parking space for 4,000 cars.
The Federal Energy Administration said today that four oil companies accused of overcharging a total of $58.2-million had already complied with agency orders to make up the cost to their customers.
During a recent visit to Paris we wrote with considerable enthusiasm of a seafood restaurant which, we stated, may be one of the two finest in that city.

Investors looking for a high rate of return for their money have been taking millions of dollars out of savings banks and borrowing millions more on the cash value in their life insurance policies.

The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City last week hit its highest mark since the weekly Market Basket Survey began in May, 1973. The 38item basket cost $61.34, a rise of 0.6 per cent over the previous week's figure of $60.95.

The dollar went into a slow decline on world money markets today, reversing a recent steady rise, in generally quiet markets. The price of gold also fell, after showing gains on all markets yesterday.
Mixing laughter and tears, the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival presented Lotte Goslar's Pantomime Circus and members of the Jose Limon Dance Company in repertory pieces for its last week.

George (Doc) Medich, the pitching medical student, carried the New York Yankees to a 4-1 victory over the Minnesota Twins yesterday and kept alive the Yankees' lingering chances in the American League East.

Francis Van Duyne Lloyd, who was Deputy Attorney General of New Jersey in 1950 and earlier was a district court judge in Bergen County, died Tuesday in Hackensack, N. J. He was 78 years old and lived in Layton, N.J. and Delray Beach, Fla.

Dr. Georgia Harkness, a theologian, educator and autor, died today of a heart attack at her home in Claremont, Calif. She was 83 years old.

Directors of the American Telephone Telegraph Company, the world's largest corporation and the most broadly owned American enterprise, voted an eight-cent increase in the quarterly dividend to 85 cents a share yesterday.

The Federal Government's move to enforce compliance with its air quality standards in Boston raises hope that the Environmental Protection Agency intends to be more like its old self where the upgrading of urban air is concerned. A 40-year-old Brooklyn man was accused of having set fire yesterday morning to the tenement in which he lived, thereby causing the death of his brother-in-law, who had earlier served him with divorce papers.

To most professional athletes, their team physician is a combination of Dr. Spock and Dr. Feelgood. He mends bruised bones and also babies proud, sensitive souls that cry out for advice and understanding. "Most players want and need coaches' approval, especially when they are injured and can't perform," Dave Meggyesy, the former linebacker of the St. Louis Cardinals, observed in "Out of Their League," an indictment of the dehumanization in football.
A pocketbook found in a trash can near City Hall on Tuesday provided a clue that led to the identification yesterday of the young woman discovered slain, on a roof in Greenwich Village.

Armed deputies blasted their way into the Potter County jail today and freed a jailer held hostage for 36 hours by-five knife-wielding inmates. The leader of the revolt was killed and three other persons were wounded in the assault.
Dr. Edward R. Schlesinger, head of the maternal and child-health programs at the University of Pittsburgh, died yesterday at Warrensburg, N.Y. He was 63 years old.

Katherine Fessenden, an author and former social worker, died Tuesday in the Cape Cod Hospital, Chatham, Mass. She was 78 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

The world's major oil-exporting nations have committed themselves to putting up the equivalent of $3.5-billion to implement an International Monetary Fund plan to help oil importers pay their higher petroleum bills, a spokesman said today.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that if President Ford dealt satisfactorily with the nation's economic ills the President would be an "extremely formidable" opponent for the Democrats in 1975.

Promising a "government of peace and development," President Alfonso Lopez Michelsen has launched in Colombia an experiment of great importance for Latin America. It is especially important because Colombia is a nation that has 'practiced democracy since 1958, one whose new President was freely elected in a landslide with large majorities in both houses of Congresss .
The Treasury Department today announced that it sold one-year bills at an average discount rate of 9.73 per cent--highest one record for such an issue.
Maunce Bembridge, a British Ryder Cup member, carded a four-underpar 66 today for a 136 to win the 36-hole Benson and Hedges individual golf championship by a stroke from Bob Charles of New Zealand.

India's Bhabha Atomic Research Center in Trombay, northeast of Bombay. It is named for Dr. Homi J. Bhabha, who was the architect of the country's atomic energy program. He was killed in a plane crash in 1966.

Thomas Stroock, a Yale graduate who moved to Wyoming in 1948, won the Republican nomination for the House by easily defeating two political unknowns yesterday.

Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo, who told the jury at his perjury trial last month that he was leaving the bench, has quietly withdrawn his retirement papers.

Panama has decided to restore diplomatic ties with Cuba, the third Latin-American nation to do so. The Panamanian National Legislation Council voted unanimously yesterday to renew the relations broken in 1962.

France will soon announce plans to ration supplies of home heating oil this winter, but does not at present envisage similar curbs for industry, a Government spokesman said today.

Prime mortgage rates on single-family dwellings were raised yesterday to records of 101/4 per cent and 10 1/2 per cent by several of California's largest savings and loan associations, reflecting continued 'pressure in the mortgage market.
The opening of the Westchester Golf Classic today produced a mob scene at the front of the 150-man pack, with four players tied for the lead at 67, five under par, and a dozen tied at 68.

Dividends of companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange, if not the companies' stocks, have been keeping pace with inflation. In the first six months this year, the companies paid out $12.5-billion, 11 per cent more than the first half last year.

Wall Street is conspicuously not giving President Ford an initial vote of confidence. In only one session-the day Mr. Ford chose Nelson Rockefeller as his Vice President-did the market manage to post a slight gain.

Robert Wilder, a journalist and publicity man who became the author of a score of popular novels, several of which were adapted for movies, died yesterday in La Jolla, Calif., where he lived. He was 73 years old.

The Penn Central Railroad reported yesterday it had a $2.2-million net railway operating profit in July. There have been only three other months, since June, 1970, when the huge system filed for bankruptcy, that Penn Central has reported an operating profit--earnings before reserves for interest obligations and leasedline rentals, which are not being paid currently.

Robert M. Morgenthau and District Attorney Richard H. Kuh yesterday disputed the merits of a proposal by Mr Morgenthau to reorganize the prosecutor's office. Under the proposal, experienced personnel, rather than junior assistants, would participate in the early screening of all cases, and the staff would be organized into teams of junior and senior assistants to oversee prosecutions "from start to finish."
A group of New York business, labor and civic leaders opened a drive yesterday to increase Federal aid for mass transportation and to save the city's 35-cent fare.

East German women mounted another attack today on world records at the European swimming championships, setting four more marks in less than an hour. Kornelia Ender, Rosemarie Kother, Renate Vogel and Ulrike Richter carved world records at Vienna's Stadionbad like hungry sharks on the rampage.

The bill passed by the Senate for the improvement of Amtrak, the national rail passenger system, provides major incentives to the states to begin regional Amtrak services.
Tim Shaw, the 16year-old Long Beach (Calif.) swimmer, broke the world 1,500-meter, free-style record tonight and became the only active competitor in the sport to hold three world marks.
Three escaped convicts disappeared today into mesquite forests in northern Texas while hundreds of lawmen moved in to end a threeday swath of killings and random violence.

A senior official of the Communist-led Pathet Lao has confirmed that Emmet J. Kay, the last known American prisoner in Indochina, would be released Sept. 12 when other prisoners of war are exchanged in Laos.

A 79-year-old man was killed yesterday when he jumped or fell in front of a subway train in the Bronx. The victim, tentatively identified as Salvatore DiPuma of 2528 Wallace Avenue, the Bronx, was struck by a southbound train at the Allerton Avenue and White Plains Road station of the IRT.

The long march toward a law that would establish Federal safeguards to take the heartbreak out of private pension programs has finally achieved first-rung success. The pension reform bill, passed by both houses of Congress and now awaiting signature by President Ford, falls far short of perfection.

Bob Berry threw two third-quarter touchdown passes to lead the Minnesota Vikings to a 32-13 National Football League exhibition victory over the Buffalo Bills tonight. It was the Vikings' first victory in three games.

In an effort to induce more prisoners to go to school, the State Department of Corrections plans to ask the Legislature to authorize payment of incentive allowances to inmates, Commissioner of Corrections Peter Preiser has disclosed.

When school opens at the University of Maryland on Wednesday, Moses Malone will not be among the incoming freshmen. The 6-foot llinch high school all-American is prepared to accept a contract with the Utah Stars that his mother said would pay him $3,000 a week for five years.

Betsy Naglesen of St. Petersburg, Fla., pulled another upset today by defeating Virginia Wade of Britain, 6-3, 3-6, 6-4, in the semifinals of the $30,000 women's grass-court tennis tournament.
Leonard Bernstein walked off the stage of the concert hall at the Opera House and fell into the arms of a member of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra in a state of mock collapse.

Three of America's leading businessmen said yesterday they were opposed to re-imposition of wage and price controls to battle inflation.

Ray Sadecki, the southpaw who ordinarily is a bull-pen tenant, turned in a full-game performance today against the Braves that had his Met teammates marveling.

The summer lull on Seventh Avenue has an air of expectancy. Manufacturers are sweating out a quiet period in the hope that retailers next month will come in with a sufficient quantity of reorders to pull the trade out of the doldrums. Reorders for all apparel are starting to trickle in, but the big volume that would lift a pall of gloom hanging over the trade is expected in September.

The economic gloom is deepening in Western nations as stock markets crumble, bankruptcies rise, inflation rages and unemployment climbs toward what many fear will be unacceptably high levels this winter.
Bluegrass music, in the past a peripheral item, at best, in the Philadelphia Folk Festival, has run rampant during the first two days of the festival's 13th annual presentation.
Crewmen from barges and lighters began efforts yesterday to refloat the 800-foot tanker Acolus, which went aground Saturday night two miles north-west of Ambrose Light When engine room flooded.

Armbro Omaha, with Peter Haughton in the sulky, won the $150,000 Prix d'Ete trot at Blue oBnnet Raceway to day. The 3-year-old colt covered the mile in 1:581-5 to win by half a length from Dorado Almahurst, driven by Benoit Cote.

Intrepid lost a protested race to her archrival Courageous, by 10 seconds at the end of a 24.3-mile course and France got close to Southern Cross before their race was abandoned because the 5 1/2-hour time limit was reached.

France will lift her embargo on arms sales to Middle East "battlefield" countries imposed in 1967 by President Charles de Gaulle. The striking National Football League Players Association voted tonight to remain in camp but rejected a new offer from the owners, sources close to the negotiations disclosed.

France will lift her embargo on arms sales to Middle East "battlefield" countries imposed in 1967 by President Charles de Gaulle. This decision is part of a fundamental review of defense policy, not yet complete but already definite on continuing French development of nuclear weapons. One aim is to convert France's submarinebased missiles to multiple independent reentry vehicles. [1:1]

Guyana will deliver 12,500 tons of sugar, valued at $7.5-million, to Venezuela in a new agreement hailed here as additional evidence of an era of friendship between the longfeuding neighboring countries.

Although Congress a decade ago passed legislation forbidding most other major employers in the nation to discriminate in hiring, it apparently feels no obligation to follow that rule of decency itself. Last week, responding to press reports of widespread discrimination on Capitol Hill, the Congressional Office of Placement and Office Management acknowledged that 80 per cent of its current job orders from Congressional offices contained exclusionary requirements.
Largely because of the tele-x vised impeachment sessions of the House Judiciary Committee last month, public confidence in Congress has increased sharply since April, according to the Gallup Poll.
Rural America prepared for its annual day in the big leagues today with 22 trotting horses ready to race for $160,150 tomorrow in the richest Hambletonian in history.
The Supreme Court was told today that the Atlantic Coast states should have no rights over oil exploration and drilling beyond the three-mile limit.
The United States, the defending champion, and Australia reached the final of the seven-nation Stevens Cup senior tennis competition at the Concorde Hotel's courts today.

A legislative narcotics study commission was reported tonight to be planning to urge the end of criminal penalties in New Jersey for the possession of small amounts of hard drugs and one ounce or less of marijuana.

Basketball is alive and well this summer at the New Jersey shore. In fact it's flourishing. The Jersey Shore Summer Basketball League, conducted on an outdoor court behind Jerry Lynch's Bar here four nights a week, is drawing an average of 1,000 fans a night. One reason: high-caliber games played by top players.

WNCN, which has attracted an intensely loyal audience in the metropolitan area with its classical music programs since 1957, will become a popularmusic station on Oct, 5.

The Western Union Corporation said today that it would discontinue the operations of its GiftAmerica, Inc., subsidiary unless new contracts were forthcoming. Western Union has written off $28.5-milion, including all GiftAmerica deferred startup costs, against 1974 earn wings.

SPETSAIS, Greece-Right after announcing withdrawal of Greek armed forces from NATO, Premier Caraman lis overhauled the command of those forces, firing all top leaders associated with the previous junta and with the boomerang Cyprus coup that touched off Turkey's invasion. The odd thing is that the men now named to command have all been pro-NATO enthusiasts.

Under pressure from the United States Government, the president of an airline that was scheduled to begin cut-rate jet flights yesterday between Tijuana, Mexico, 115 miles south of here, and Luxembourg said today that the service had been postponed indefinitely.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation said in Pittsburgh yesterday that it had been advised by the LTV Corporation, its principal shareholder, that LTV intended to acquire the remaining publicly owned shares of Merger the steel company.

British Airways reported today its new profit jumped to $38.5-million in the year ended March 31, from $12.8-million a year earlier. But Chairman David Nicholson forecast a loss of as much as $48-million in fiscal 1975.

Sixteen persons were injured tonight when the bus in which they were riding crashed into two unoccupied parked cars on a shoulder of Interstate 84 here, the state police said. Two persons were listed in fair condition date tonight at Danbury Hospital. Fourteen others were treated for minor injuries and released from area hospitals. s.

The 758-year-old Dominican Order today chose a new head, or master general. The Very Rev. Vincent de Couesnongle, a Frenchman, was elected for a 12-year term at a meeting of the order's general chapter at the ancient Shrine of Sant'Anastasia near Naples.
President Ford said today that the United States would act in concert with the rest of the Organization of American States in any moves to improve relations with Cuba.

Two United States concerns today asked the Finance Ministry for permission to list their stocks on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, ministry sources reported. The sources identified the companies as Borden Inc., a food and chemical manufacturer, and the Chase Manhattan Banking Corporation, both of New York.

Congressional and Coast Guard investigators agreed today that drug runners bent on hijacking yachts and other pleasure boats to use in plying their trade were a definite menace to mariners, particularly in the Caribbean and adjacent waters. Comdr. Marshall Phillips of the Coast Guard pointing to an area off Florida where vessels have been hijacked in drug-related cases. He testified before a House Merchant Marine and Fisheries subcommittee yesterday.

Rhodesia has announced a new national anthem-the "Ode to Joy" from Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. The new anthem comes five years after the secessionist British colony abandoned "God Save, the Queen."

The Saudi Arabian Government withdrew more than 500,000 ounces of its gold held at the Federal. Reserve Bank of New York during July, Commerce Department statistics showed today. The transfer totaled 516,577 ounces valued at $21,811,039 at the official price of $42.22 an ounce.

State Attorney General William F. Hyland said today that he would support legislation that "decriminalized" drug addiction and the personal use of marijuana in New Jersey. Attorney General William F. Hyland at news conference before interview on narcotics penalties.

The Soviet Union has a numerical edge of more than three to one over the United States in submarines, has more than five times as many cruisers and has started to challenge America's long supremacy in aircraft carriers, the authoritative Jane's Fighting Ships says in its 1974-75 edition, to be issued tomorrow.
Landlords are abandoning about 300 buildings a month in the city, for a loss of about 36,. 000 apartments a year, according to Roger Starr, the Housing and Development Administrator.
A national assembly of dissenting moderates in the Lutheran Church Missouri Synod has overwhelmingly endorsed staying in the denomination until a they are forced out by the con- e servative majority.
The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers agreed today to submit for membership approval a modified wage package covering 60,000 striking Western Electric Company workers nationwide.

An opinion poll on voter sentiment taken prior to the May 14 municipal elections in Paterson was produced at a hearing by the Election Law Enforcement Commission here today as evidence seeking to show that Mayor Lawrence Kramer tried to evade state campaign-spending limits.

An organization called Operation Freedom, headed by former Representative Hamilton Fish Sr., placed a half-page advertisement in three newspapers Tuesday and yesterday urging that former President Richard M. Nixon not be prosecuted for his involvement in the Watergate cover-up.

The Boy Scouts of America has denied allegations of racial discrimination in troops sponsored by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and asked for dismissal of a lawsuit by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
Alaskans decided yesterday that it was time to move the Governor's mansion, state office buildings and seat of government inland.
When Greece accepted the Soviet proposal for an international conference on Cyprus, she warned the Russians that she did not want to participate in another "propaganda forum."

Although the opening day for many public schools is only a week away, 228 school districts in the state have yet to reach contract agreements with teachers.

Roger W. Straus Jr., the book publisher, said yesterday that his company, Farrar, Straus Giroux, had been told by a "reliable intermediary" this month that former President Richard M. Nixon "would entertain an offer of $2-million" for the rights to publish his memoirs.

WASHINGTON --Nothing succeeds like succession: The suddenness of President Ford's emergence, the delight with which he is widely embraced for the virtue of not being his predecessor, and the correctness of his demeanor have combined to create the atmosphere of success in which success is more likely to be achieved.

Leaders in the beleaguered housing industry said yesterday that only vigorous action by the Ford Administration provided a prospect for prompt recovery from the industry's severe slump. Housing construction under way on Long Island recently. Housing starts continued to fall last month.

Late returns from the Democratic primary in Oklahoma yesterday brought defeat to Gov. David Hall's effort to succeed himself in office and to gain a national political reputation. David L. Boren, left, State Representative, and Representative Clem R. McSpadden after clinching runoff spots for Democratic governorship primary in Oklahoma.

President Ford struck just the right balance yesterday in responding to questions about his views on future litigation affecting former President Nixon. Mr. Ford recognized Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski's obligations as a law-enforcement officer of the United States to explore all aspects of the Watergate cases, including Mr. Nixon's involvement. The President also noted his own pardoning power, but refused to make an untimely commitment as to how he would use that power.

President Ford has signed a bill appropriating $3.2-billion for the Department of Transportation and related agencies, a spokesman announced today. The total appropriation represented a cut of $256-million, or nearly 7 per cent from the original request.

Premier Bulent Ecevit urged today that "national excitement" over Turkey's military success In Cyprus be turned toward overcoming this country's problems in economic development and social justice. In his first political trip outside Ankara since the Cyprus crisis erupted six weeks ago, Mr. Ecevit received a hero's welcome in this industrial city 60 miles east of Istanbul.

President Ford said that any United States move to improve relations with Cuba would be taken in concert with the Organization of American States. He said it was up to Cuba to change her policy first. His reply to a question at his first formal Presidential news conference came as moves were under way in the O.A.S. to lift its 1974 embargo on trade and diplomatic relations with the Castro regime in Cuba. [1:4.]

The United States Export-Import Bank said today it had approved loans to help finance the purchase of six McDonnell Douglas Corporation jets valued at $108.5-million and four Lockheed Aircraft Corporation planes valued at $68-million to three foreign airlines.

The 14-day cooling-off period in the National Football League players' strike passed yesterday without any settlement. The Players' Association voted in Chicago against accepting the revised package by the N.F.L. Management Council, 25-1. No mention was made of the player representative who cast the only dissenting vote.

The latest Government-sponsored study of the effects of air pollution, particularly in the nation's largest cities, shows that automobile fumes are causing what appalled medical researchers call an "astonishing" threat to the health of vast numbers of persons.
The United States retained the Stevens Cup by defeating Australia, 2-1, in the final of the international senior tennis competition at the Concord Hotel today.

The farm commodity markets finished with a strong rally yesterday after tentative opening and irregular movements until the last minutes of trading. Soybeans, which were down the limit in the last two days, led the comeback in the final moments of trading and rose the limit.
The United States retained the Stevens Cup by defeating Australia, 2-1, in the final of the international senior tennis competition at the Concord Hotel today.

A simple memorial service was held yesterday for Charles A. Lindbergh. Friends and family gathered at the tiny Kipahulu Hawaiian Church to honor the aviation pioneer. He was buried in a lava-stone grave next to the 19th-century church Monday after his death from cancer. He was 72 years old.
Federal prosecutors opposed notions by C. Arnholt Smith and Philip A. Toft to have the indictment against them dismissed and evidence in the case against them suppressed.
Prices of the better-grade corporate and tax-exempt bonds were marked up a half-point or so early yesterday as the sales of the week's big offerings progressed beyond expectations.

Major American industries are blaming the energy crisis, economic and environmental controls and high interest rates for shortages of critical materials that could further increase the prices of consumer goods.
Directors of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, the nation's ninth largest steel producer, yesterday declared the company's first dividend on its common stock in 10 years.

A 13-year-old Brooklyn girl was wounded in a police crossfire yesterday afternoon as the police shot and captured an armed man they had sought to question about a slaying in a Bay Ridge gas station on Monday.

Opening day at the United States Open tennis championships in Forest Hills, Queens, provided surprises, tiffs and sultry weather yesterday, but not the sort a fan had come to expect. John Newcombe, left, shaking hands with Ramiro Benavides after defeating him yesterday at Forest Hills. Ilie Nastase trying on a hat taken from linesman at Forest Hills. He gave it back.

Three top-ranked New York experts will be missing when the traditional Knickerbocker Championships begin tonight at the New York Hilton Hotel. Peter Weichsel and Alan Sontag will be in Washington, competing for the right to represent North America in the 1975 World Team Championship.

City Council President Paul O'Dwyer yesterday deplored the award of a contract for bread and rolls to a New Jersey company. The $497,617 contract for supplies to Manhattan public schools went to the Lazzara Bakery of Paterson, which bid lower than a New York City firm, Silvercup, by only $1,745, Mr. O'Dwyer said.

Careful; that may be soap soup bubbling on Rose Goldemberg's kitchen stove; the dinner stew is on the other burner. It's not uncommon for Mrs. Goldemberg to be cooking a family meal at the same time she's simmering a batch of cream or shampoo. (The soap soup is a base of some of her cosmetics).

Concern over Turkish military intervention in Cyprus transformed the routine loan today of an old United States amphibious landing craft to Turkey into a controversial move assailed by citizens and members of Congress.

Karl Keller, who retired in 1955 as chairman of the Keuffel Esser Company, manufacturer and importer of scientific instruments, died on Tuesday at his home, 20 Beacon Road, Summit, N. J. He was 94 years old.
A Soviet' minesweeper entered waters off Israell-held territory' for the fourth consecutive day today and was turned back by an Israeli patrol boat, the military command said.
They call it an open administration and the people' a President Ford's White House did their best today to convey that feeling at his first news conference.

The Saratoga Festival could hardly be accused of thinking small when it got around last night to mounting the first fully staged opera in its nine-year history. The opera chosen was the complete Rimsky-Korsakov version of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov." It began shortly after 8 last night in the Saratoga Performing. Arts Center and it didn't end until 12:20 this morning.
They don't often postpone horse races because of bad weather, but they did it here today when rain forced a 24-hour delay in the $160,150 Hambletonian, the prestige event of the trotting world.

Ed Kirkpatrick hit a double that scored two runs in the 11th inning today carrying the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 3:1 victory over the San Francisco Giants. It was the sixth straight triumph for the Pirates.
The city is negotiating with the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad to buy the line's 100-acre Mott Haven Yard in the South Bronx and turn it into an industrial park.

LATIN FLAIR The Chateau Madrid is one of the leaders of the establishment when it comes to Spanish and Latin-flavored entertainment. For 16 years it was on West 58th Street, and then six years ago it moved to the Lexington Hotel, Lexington Avenue and 48th Street Last week, the ownership changed hands, and the Chateau Madrid (PL 28080) decided to bask in its success by keeping its doors open Tuesday evenings.
The Government's measure of future trends in the economy rebounded in July on the strength of an improved job picture and labor costs, the Commerce Department reported today.

After dealing with 340 proposed amendments, "delegates to the World Population Conference tonight, were completing a "plan of action," a set of suggested guidelines for nations in formulating population policies.

The Philco-Ford Corporation of Blue Bell, Pa., announced yesterday an averaged price increase on its refrigerators of 9.3 per cent, the third increase this year. The rise is effective Sept. 1. An earlier increase of 6.2 per cent was applied at the beginning of July and another of 5 per cent in March.
A fire swept through a pavilion at Moscow's principal exhibition grounds today, burning out the structure and forcing Western businessmen and. Soviet workmen to. leap through windows to safety.

With the Sept. 10 primary election less than two weeks away, the city and the union representing full-time employes of the Board of Elections were still far apart yesterday on settlement of a new labor contract two months after the old one expired.
With the ease of a fighter hitting a punching bag, Southern Cross routed blue-hulled France again today and earned the right to challenge for the America's Cup.

The Agricultural Commissioner of the European Economic Community, ending two days of talks with Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, said today that good wheat crops in the member countries would make it possible for them to restrain imports of United States corn and other livestock feed grains. Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, left, and Pierre Lardinois, Common Market Agriculture Commissioner, during their news conference in Washington yesterday.

The General Electric Company's nuclear division has told the Atomic Energy Commission that it has extensive problems with the advanced technology being used in its fuel-recovery plant near Chicago and may decide to scrap the project.

Seven men have been executed by a Moroccan firing squad for their part in an armed uprising against King Hassan II last year, defense lawyers said today. The uprising was alleged to have been masterminded by leftist emigres.
The City Planning Commission yesterday backed the designation of two sections of townhouses and other low-rise residential buildings in the East Nineties as the Carnegie Hill historic district.
The manned spaceship Soyuz 15 returned abruptly to earth today, apparently having failed to achieve. a link-up with the Soviet orbital station Salyut 3.

It has long been obvious that a satisfactory Cyprus solution would have to be worked out at several different levels; and it would be well, therefore, if everyone concerned would stop quibbling about-different "forums" and get on with essential preliminaries. One such preliminary is the convening of the United Nations Security Council today to take up the problem of the 200,000 Cypriotes displaced by Turkey's military advance.

Suits filed by five companies alleging antitrust violations by the Caterpillar Tractor Company have been settled out of court, a Caterpillar spokesman said today.

The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, in a brief aimed at defending a controversial cost-adjustment clause against a challenge by the Public Advocate, contended today that the clause had enabled it to put off a request for a rate increase by 18 months.

Labor Day holiday travelers should have little trouble finding gasoline, according to the American Automobile Association. Secretary of State Kissinger was criticized and defended in the Israeli Parliament here today. Haim Landau of the opposition Likud party, a generally pro-American group, listed a number of grievances and said the Secretary was seeking to press Israel to surrender territory step by step.

Lacking any encouraging news, prices on the American Stock Exchange declined again yesterday, marking the 14th consecutive session to show a drop. Prices in the over-the-counter market were mixed.

A formula 5000 race and two International Race of Champions events will make up the Riverside Grand Prix. Prix.
