Gov. Dolph Briscoe of Texas ordered today a special court of inquiry int othe prison-escape attempt by Fred Gonmez Carrasco after reports thatMr. Carrasco and another inmate may have been killed by the police.

Mimi Jane Green, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. Russell Green of New York and Klosters, Switzerland, was married here yesterday morning to Thomas Coleman Dillenberg. son of Mrs. Walter D. Yankhouer and the late D. Alan Dillenberg.

To the Editor: The Fortune Society, a group staffed by, and for, ex-convicts, is viewing the nation's debate about imprisonment for political felons of the recent Presidential Administration with interest. The .verbiage among academia, the media, and the remains-of the legal aristocracy, seems to be way off target.
Thousands of students were bused across town without incident today on the first day of class under a Federal court order requiring complete integration of the 80,000-pupil public school system.

HONOLULU-Today, all America is debating whether Citizen Nixon should be prosecuted and punished for the "Watergate crimes" of President Nixon. Some hold that he has been punished enough. Others wish him jailed to prove that Justice is impartial.

Howard J. Samuels, Democratic gubernatorial aspirant, was named today in a $2.15-million lawsuit that accused him of being an "active director" of a firm that had allegedly deceived a California investor.

Once East Germany stopped harassing travelers on the roads that link West Germany with West Berlin, there was no reason for the United States to delay the opening of diplomatic relations with the so-called German Democratic Republic. The scheduled signing in Washington on Wednesday of an agreement to exchange ambassadors will clear the way for former Senator John Sherman Cooper to take up his post as this country's first envoy in East Berlin.

Four companies are banding together to create what they call the first commercial complex to use solar energy for heating and cooling the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) reports. Rendering of part of the commercial complex that four concerns are planning. Solar power would be used to provide energy and heating for the structure.

Thomas and Erika Gribble shopping in Frankfurt. They have learned to accommodate to West Germany's mild inflation.

Earl Bush, former press aide to Mayor Richard J. Daley, was acquitted today of nine counts of mail fraud and one count of extortion, but a Federal jury Failed to reach a verdict on 11 other counts of mail fraud. Express bus service for 20,000 commuters between the Bronx and Manhattan will resume by Sept. 9, the Riverdale Transit Corporation announced yesterday, after a settlement of the nine-week-old strike by members of Local 225 of the Transport Workeds Union.

Atlantic Coast Conference is continuing to investigate the recruitment of Moses Malone and also is investigating three other basketball recruitment cases, said the conference commissioner, Robert James. James, speaking at Wake Forest University, revealed that the recruitment of Phil Ford, a Rocky Mount native signed to a letter of intent by North Carolina, is being investigated. But he declined to say who the other two athletes were.
Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, in a letter to The Washington Post, took issue today with the newspaper's use of the word "leniency" in the headline of an article regarding his legal problems.
Norman P. Smith, a former partner and vice president in Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, who had headed its-syndicate department, died yesterday in Venice (Fla.) Hospital.

The Rev. Dr. George Ernest Wright, Near Eastern archeologist, Biblical scholar and Parkman Professor of Divinity at Harvard University, died Thursday in Jaffrey, N. H. He was 64 years old and lived in Lexington, Mass.

Jimmy Connors returning a serve by Jeff Borowlak yesterday at Forest Hills. Connors won, 6-3, 6-4, 3-6, 7-5. Stan Smith in backhand return to Jaime Fillol. Smith won, 3-6, 6-3, 5-7, 7-5, 7-6.

The rapid buildup of inventories in the manufacturing sector of the economy continued in July with the largest rise in dollar value of inventories so far this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

Henry N. Muller, former vice president and, technical director of the National Electrical Manufacturers- Association, died of cancer Thursday in Hanover, N.H. He was 60 years old.

The stock market paused in its three-week slide yesterday as a strong technical rally 'advanced prices sharply in heavier trading. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 21.74 points to 678.58. Since Aug. 7 the average had dropped 140.72 points.
Yields on Treasury bills declined today as the Government auctioned $4.8-billion of short-term securities in a financing moved ahead from Monday because of Labor Day.

President Ford correctly recognizes that a major responsibility for inflation rests on Government itself. TIis responsibility extends beyond the excessive creation of money and swollen Federal expenditures, of which the defense budget is a prime example. The Government's pernicious role as a feeder of inflation also embraces a host of activities designed to prop up or increase prices and institutionalize inefficiencies.

One measure, effective Sunday, outlaws the harassing of tenants by relocation companies-by the withholding of services or Initiation of spurious servicesto force the tenants to move from buildings scheduled for demolition. Yesterday a law barring chain, or pyramid, distributor schemes in the state went into effect. Both laws were approved by the 1974 session of the State Legislature.

One of the bluest of the blue-chip British banks, Lloyds Bank, Ltd., announced today that it has suffered losses of up to $75-million because of "irregularities," including unauthorized foreign exchange dealings at its branch in Lugano, Switzerland, near the Italian border.

The output of the nation's economy fell in the first quarter of this year by $10-billion to $20-billion as a result of the Arab oil embargo, according to a report released in Washington by the Federal Energy Administration.
The hopes of Rumanian Communist leaders to bring the Soviet Union and China closer through Contacts at meetings here during the last two weeks have apparently evaporated.

President Ford is committed to doing something for the nation's capitalstarved utilities, but the question is what? Borrowing costs are astronomical today and some utilities have withdrawn issues of bonds, deferring vital power projects rather than pay an unacceptably high price for money.

Schmitt, who was born and raised in the New York area and played his entire college and pro football career here, was traded by the Jets, today to the Green Bay Packers on a conditional basis for the ubiquitous undisclosed future draft choice.

The finals of the American Song Festival began at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center here at 7:45 last night,'45 minutes late. They ended, for all practical purposes, at 5:55 A.M. today, when Skitch Henderson of the judges' panel announced the festival grand-. prize winner.

The National Council on the Arts marked today the 10th anniversary of its creation and the first Congressional legislation created to support and encourage the arts.

The Labor Day setting was perfect for President Ford to sign a law that in his words "will probably give more benefits and rights and success in the area of labor-management than almost anything in the history of the country."
The Dow Chemical Company plans to spend more than $165-million to expand its Louisiana division complex in Iberville and West Baton Rouge parishes.

Rauf Denktash, head of the Turkish Cypriote administration, said today that Greece and the Greek Cypriote Government had privately conceded that Cyprus would be formally divided into two zones, one for the ethnic Greeks and the other for the Turkish community.

Kenneth A. Gibson continued to counter high emotion with calm today as he held a round of meetings with his staff and with leaders of the Hispanic community to discuss ways of cooling tempers after two days of disturbances.

Farm commodity futures plunged yesterday in Chicago, as a wave of liquidation overpowered strong opening prices on the Board of Trade. And in New York most futures prices were down also led by jittery traders of precious metals and doleful potato men who fear an avalanche of Maine spuds.

President Ford and Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, will have their first meeting tomorrow afternoon at a time of real uncertainty about the new President's position on the environment and willingness to spend large amounts of Federal money to improve it. Verdi's "Aida"-the opera commissioned for the opening of the Suez Canal in' 1869--will be performed here again next summer when the canal reopens, the newspaper Al Ahram said today.

The European Common Market promised its 10 million farmers today that it would take measures later this month to increase their incomes. But it still faced the difficult problem of how to act without aggravating an already severe inflation. A scene in Bremen yesterday as farmers protested low market prices for their products

Nobody really tries to figure out the Pittsburgh Pirates anymore. All that's known for certain is that the Pirate crew is a hardy band of individualists, at times given to mutiny, who presently rule the seas in the National League East and threaten to take no hostages.

Hllinois today became the 47th state with a campaign finance disclosure law. Gov. Daniel Walker signed legislation requiring candidates for state and local office and their campaign committees to report contributions of $150 or more.

Amid inflation-related rising costs, pressures for higher salaries and pinched family budgets, religious schools serving nearly three-quarters of a mild lion pupils in the metropolitan New York area and in New Jersey begin opening their doors this week for a new school year.

Pro basketball has lost what once was its greatest and most complete player. Oscar Robertson, after 14 seasons and many contract disputes, announced his retirement last night. The 37year-old Robertson, who became a free agent when the Milwaukee Bucks failed to offer him a new contract last month, will take his basketball knowledge to the television microphones.

Some of the relics of the Sioux Indian's past--a war bonnet, peace pipes, tomahawks and the likewill be on display from Tuesday through Oct. 15 at the Donnell Library. And there will also be a storytelling part of the program to give those relics life.
Wood-hulled Intrepid will return in 1977 with her "nickel, dime and dollar" West Coast effort in quest of an elusive third America's Cup defense.

Weiss, Peck Greer, a diversified Wall. Street brokerage firm, announced yesterday that it would merge with Brokaw, Schaenen, Clancy Co., a small investment management firm here with a number of bluechip corporate pension accounts.

Ken Rosewall and Arthur Ashe, who know their way around, found their way out of trouble and into the quarterfinals of the United States Open tennis championships yesterday in Forest Hills, Queens. Arthur Ashe, left, 1968 champion, defeating ninth-seeded Guillermo Vilas at Forest Hills to gain quarterfinals. Ken Rosewall, left, 1970 champion, also made quarterfinals by defeating Raul Ramirez in four sets yesterday.

Despite expansion of its routes, the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority (MABSTOA) has had a sharp drop in ridership and last year had an operating loss of $5.6.million, its first in a decade, State Controller Arthur Levitt reported yesterday.

Valert Borzov, the Soviet Union's double Olympic sprint champion in 1972, rose to the occasion again today to win his third straight title at the European track and field championships in Rome's Stadio Olympico. Borzov won...

One of England's most controversial politicians, Enoch Powell, was chosen by the hardline Ulster Unionist party tonight as a candidate for the British Parliament.

State Department officials disclosed yesterday that East Germany has agreed to discuss possible compensation for Jews and other victims of Nazism following today's establishment of diplomatic relations. In contrast with West, Germany, the East Germans previously refused to pay, but Washington made it clear during recent talks that unless the matter was formally negotiated there would be no diplomatic recognition from this country-and no trade relations..

The Communist party newspaper Pravda today sounded a fresh note of Soviet displeasure over the setting up of a -West German environmental office in West Berlin, contending that its presence created "serious concern and anxiety among the world democratic public."

The Federal Trade Commission announced its final acceptance today of a negotiated settlement requiring a Miami land development company to refund nearly $3-million collected for parcels of land in Florida and Arizona.

Representative Hugh L. Carey reversed himself yesterday and told Howard J. Samuels, his Democratic gubernatorial primary opponent, that he would endorse him should Mr. Samuels win the primary election next Tuesday. Representative Hugh L Carey of Brooklyn, leg listening to Howard J. Samuels, his rival in the contest for Democratic nomination for Governor, during debate at The Times.
The Citizens Union yesterday endorsed candidates for Senate, Assembly and City Council races in next Tuesday's Democratic primary.

ATLANTA (NL)--Called up Mike Beard, lefthanded pitcher, from Savannah of the Southern League. NEW YORK (AL)-Recalled Fred Stanley, infielder, from Syracuse of the International League. Purchased Larry Murray, outfielder, from Fort Lauderdale of the Florida State League.
Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said today that the Arabs should continue to use oil as a weapon to obtain political objects.
The credit market began the week on a cautious note yesterday, with prices of fixed-interest securities moving narrowly in the absence of trend-setting major offerings.

Six members of a French family barricaded themselves inside the French Consulate today and one said, "We have enough gasoline to burn down the building and we're willing to burn with it unless we get justice."
Widely scattered torrential rainstorms yesterday evening caused power failures and flooding of subways and highways, in the metropolitan area.

July construction fell 0.7 per cent, or $900-million, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $137.2-billion, the Commerce Department reported today. The department revised upward $2.1-billion the figure for June, which was reported provisionally at $136billion.

East Germany has agreed for the first time to hold discussions on the possible compensation of Jewish victims of Nazism, State Department officials said today. The talks would come sometime after tomorrow's establishment of diplomatic relations with the United States.
Jim Dietz of the New York Athletic Club was ready to face a big challenge as he made final preparations today for the world rowing championships.
An investigation into "questionable" credit dealings with the Tropicana Hotel casino here is being conducted by the Nevada State Gaming Control Board, a board member said today.
The South Korean Ambassador warned today that his nation's relations with Japan had reached a "dangerous" and "delicate" stage.

Edward J. Byrnes, assistant customer service manager of The New York Times, died Monday of cancer. He was 50 years old and lived at 7224 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn.

There are indications that Chile's military rulers may be contemplating the release of some of the thousands of persons still held for political reasons a year after the overthrow of President Salvador Allende. Nothing could do more to improve the international standing of Gen. Augusto Pinochet's Government.
An agreement was signed here today giving the government of Abu Dhabi a 60 per cent share of the Abu Dhabi Petroleum Company, retroactive to January, 1974.
Carlos Ricci, central bank president, announced today that Uruguay would soon allow unrestricted buying of foreign currency.

Gen. Alexander M. Haig, Jr., chief of the White House staff, is expected to be appointed supreme commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and of United States forces in Europe by President Ford, two authoritative Administration officials said today. Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. 'Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster, present NATO commander.

Indictments against seven major oil companies. charging them with criminally acting together to restrain competition in the sale of gasoline throughout the metropolitan area, have been voted by a special state grand jury.
Two senior officials of the Italian neoFascist party were questioned today by a state prosecutor investigating the terrorist bombing of a train last month in which 12 persons were killed.
Correcting errors that city maps and record books have carried for more than 70 years, Mayor Beame signed legislation yesterday correcting the misspellings of three streets.
